documents.title: prime minister 's questions : 'score draw in the vauxhall conference '
text: ho-hum .
another scrappy score draw in the vauxhall conference .

the prime minister seemed surprised that jeremy corbyn chose to attack on council cuts - and his opening question on the woes of ( conservative controlled ) northamptonshire county council , now effectively bankrupt and recommended for abolition , left her discomforted .

but as mr corbyn pivoted from northants to surrey and leicestershire , theresa may recovered herself and started citing examples of quitting labour council leaders and labour activists switching to her party .
maybe the fact that she had such obvious lines of retaliation available to her explained her surprise .

perhaps mr corbyn 's most effective moment came when he pointed to the impact of rising business rates - a subject that genuinely worries many conservatives - but he did not press that attack very far .
in many ways this was a prototy may-corbyn exchange - him : cuts are bad '' her : labour would be worse . ''
parliamentary artistry it is n't .
perhaps the most politically interesting aspect of this session was the exchanges on fisheries .
the government knows it is in a difficult position over the transitional deal it has struck with the eu .
fishing communities which hoped to see britain pull out of the common fisheries policy on brexit day have been disappointed - and infuriated .
scottish conservative mps , many of whom would lose their seats if their fisher-folk turned against them , are deeply worried and have already expressed their disappointment .
they were discouraged from doing so again , today .
but the intervention from brexiteer ex-minister mark francois demonstrated that it is not just constituency interest that drives backbench tory disquiet .
there are plenty of tories who are very disappointed on ideological grounds - and are putting down markers against a longer-term compromise of fishing rights after the transition .

the pm came prepared with a carefully-worded answer on this issue but she knows it will not go away and that she faces a real dilemma - because the electoral cost of failure on this issue could be a reverse of those vital tory gains in scotland .
the snp 's drew hendry cashed in on tory discomfort but his leader , ian blackford , raised the cambridge analytica saga , detailing the links between the company and conservative party figures .
the pm did not enjoy that - and it may have been mr blackford 's most effective moment at pmqs since assuming the snp 's westminster leadership .
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: bid to put belfast agreement principles into brexit billeu withdrawal bill
text: conservative lord patten of barnes introduces an amendment which would require ministers exercising any of the powers under this bill to have regard to the principles and obligations contained in the belfast agreement .
he highlights the `` very difficult problem '' of the irish border and claims that most of those proposing technological solutions `` have never been to northern ireland and have no idea '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: princess hospital in harlow congratulatedurgent question : nhs pay
text: conservative robert halfon says that his local hospital in harlow is now out of special measures .
he he says the hospital struggles to attract staff as it is so close to london , meaning recruitment becomes an issue .
he asks mr hunt to look at pay scales in the future .
mr hunt says that he is very proud of the hospital moving out of special measures .
he adds that he recognises the `` capital issues '' at that hospital , and the fact that the building currently being used is `` not fit for purpose '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pfi bills in the nhs questionedurgent question : nhs pay
text: labour 's stella creasy says that her local hospital has had to try and decrease nurse pay in order to bring their pfi payments into line .
the hospital also has an agency staffing rate of 17 % , she adds .
she asks what is being done to decrease the pfi bill .
mr hunt says the government has stopped the `` disastrous '' pfi deals which led to these consequences .
the government has given some financial relief to some of these hospitals , but he will look once again at her hospital in particular , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour mp questions spending on agency staffurgent question : nhs pay
text: labour mp bambos charalambous says nhs trusts are spending £ 3bn a year on agency staff to `` plug gaps in the workforce '' .
he asks whether this means the previous nhs pay cap has been `` totally self-defeating '' .
in reply jeremy hunt says the `` mushrooming '' agency fees was the `` realisation post-mid staffs '' that more nurses were needed .
however the agency bill is being brought down and should be `` significantly lower '' this year , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: health committee chair welcomes pay dealurgent question : nhs pay
text: chair of the health committee and tory mp sarah wollaston says she welcomes today 's announcement on pay and is pleased it will come from new funding , not existing resources .
she asks what will be done about improving staff retention rates and career progression .
mr hunt says under the agreement there will be an `` important new partnership '' between nhs employers and the unions to implement the results of the stevenson-palmer review .
he adds that changes to the pay increments system will give staff the opportunity to increase their pay as their skills increase .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: hunt : 'loss of control of public finances ' led to pay capurgent question : nhs pay
text: health secretary jeremy hunt asks why labour in wales has continued to deprive the nhs of funding it needs .
he says that the `` pay restraint '' in the nhs since the conservatives came to office was caused by a `` catastrophic loss of control of public finances '' after the financial crisis .
he adds that the starting rate of pay for a health care assistant in the nhs will see a 26 % increase in pay , a nurse 's pay will go up by 25 % and a band six paramedic will see a rise of £ 4000 .
mr hunt says that this comes from extra money from the treasury , as a result of the chancellor 's spring statement which announced that debt as a proportion of gdp had fallen .
he says that in other european countries , governments are putting less funding into their health systems .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour 'vindicated ' by nhs pay riseurgent question : nhs pay
text: shadow health secretary jon ashworth says labour and the trade unions have been `` vindicated '' in their argument that a pay rise for nhs staff is `` long overdue '' .
however he says the government 's nhs pay cap `` should have been scrapped years ago '' .
he asks how the pay rise will be paid for , given that a nurse in the general election who asked for a pay-rise on tv was told `` there is no magic money tree '' by the prime minister .
he says jeremy hunt has `` backed down '' on plans to cut an extra day 's holiday as part of the deal , and asks for a guarantee this will not be asked for again .
he asks when `` the rest of the public sector '' will get a pay deal of their own .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: nhs staff pay to increase - hunturgent question : nhs pay
text: health and social care secretary jeremy hunt says that today 's agreement on a new pay deal reflects the public appreciation of nhs staff following a challenging winter .
it is a something for something deal , he says , meaning that there will be changes to working practices in order to ensure value for money from the nhs ' £ 36bn staff pay bill .

the new pay agreement will mean that automatic small increases in pay will go , to be replaced by agreed larger , but less frequent , increases in pay when staff have reached agreed milestones by their manager .
the lowest starting salary in the nhs will increase by over £ 2500 .
other changes include buying and selling annual leave as well as shared parental leave for nhs staff .
`` rarely has a pay rise been so well deserved for nhs staff , '' he finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: urgent question for health ministers on nhs payurgent question : nhs pay
text: the shadow health and social care secretary jonathan ashworth is asking an urgent question on nhs pay .
it was announced this morning that the government plans to sign off a new pay deal for nhs workersf , expected to raise pay for 1.3m staff of at least 6.5 % over three years .
the deal is expected to be agreed between unions and ministers later today , and will mean a £ 4bn cash injection for staff pay to the nhs .
the deal would mean this pay would be granted almost immediately and is also tiered , meaning that those on the lowest wages get the biggest increases .
the deal is for all of those on the agenda for change contract , which is the entire workforce except doctors , dentists and senior leaders .
our political editor , laura kuenssberg , has written an analysis of the situation .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pm urged to join campaign against vaginal meshprime minister 's questions
text: labour 's fiona onasanya raises the issue of vaginal mesh and asks if the pm will join the campaign to `` sling the mesh '' .
theresa may recognises it is a `` very important issue '' and undertakes to write to her about it .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pm congratulates raf on 100 years of serviceprime minister 's questions
text: labour 's albert owen offers condolences for the raf engineer killed in his constituency yesterday .
he asks if the prime minister will commemorate the raf on its 100 years of service to the uk .
mrs may says that the uk should recognise the `` valour '' that all those who serve in the raf give the uk .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: shot across the bowsprime minister 's questions
text: a shot across the bows from brexiteer mark francois about the transitional deal on fisheries .
this reflects considerable backbench disquiet about this aspect of the deal , and the possible electoral consequences , if fisheries communities are not happy .
scottish conservatives have not added to their earlier statements , but the backbench brexiteers have now weighed in .
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: pm : uk to 'take back control ' of fishing watersprime minister 's questions
text: conservative mark francois says he has `` concerns '' about the transitional deal on fishing , where nothing will change for its duration .
he asks the prime minister to assure him `` we will absolutely and unequivocally take back control of our waters from 2021 '' .

theresa may says the `` the point about the implementation period is that people can move to make the changes necessary '' and that a transition where little changes avoids too many `` cliff edge changes '' .
but she says she wants to reassure the fishing community that the government will `` ensure that we do take back control of our waters '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: calls for a digital bill of rightsprime minister 's questions
text: calls for a digital bill of rights , dealing with issues like online abuse and data security look certain to resurface when the data protection bill returns to the commons , probably after easter .
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: uk needs a 'digital guard dog ' - plaid cymruprime minister 's questions
text: plaid cymru 's leader at westminster liz saville roberts says that last year the government considered a statutory code of practice for social media corporations .
she asks if the government will now consider a `` digital guard dog '' which `` both barks , and bites '' .
mrs may says the government has taken the view that the first step is to sit down with the industry and working with them .
they know that if that does n't work then the government will consider legislation , she adds .
she condemns the `` sorry state of affairs '' in political discourse online in the uk .
she says that people should be able to express their opinions online without expecting abuse for it .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: tory mp speaks of 'anxiety ' among fishing communitiesprime minister 's questions
text: conservative anne-marie trevelyan tells the pm fishermen and women in berwick are `` very anxious '' about the news that the common fisheries policy will apply until 2020 and there is `` real concern the eu will take advantage of us losing our voice in the cfp '' .
theresa may stresses there `` needs to be certainty '' for the coming years but she 's determined to `` take back control of our waters '' .
she says quotas will not be changed and fishers will not be denied access to other waters .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour mp questions funds for children 's mental healthprime minister 's questions
text: labour mp ellie reeves says funding for children 's mental health services is being `` constantly cut '' .
in some areas many children wait up to 18 months to receive treatment , she says .
theresa may replies however that the government is putting `` more funding into mental health provision '' .
ministers have also committed that by 2020/21 , an extra 70,000 children and young people will have access to nhs mental healthcare , she adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pm offers 'recognition ' of important role of finance in brexit dealprime minister 's questions
text: conservative bim afolami talks about the importance of financial services to his constituents in hitchin and harpenden .
he asks what progress the government is making on getting an agreement on financial services as part of the brexit deal .

theresa may says she 's `` very well aware of the importance of financial services '' to both his constituency and the country at large , and that she also knows about the `` important role the city of london plays for the whole of the eu '' .
she says the government is in discussion with the eu on the issue and that there is a `` recognition '' of that role .
she says it 's `` important we retain access to finance from across the european union '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: may rejects criticism of council fundingprime minister 's questions
text: labour 's mohammad yasin talks about the people of bedford who are `` worried '' about cuts `` ruining the prospects of our town '' .
theresa may tells him there are more good or outstanding schools in bedford as well as extra funding for the health service

documents.title: pm congratulates santanderprime minister 's questions
text: conservative pauline latham talks about her constituent who set up the 'dying to work ' campaign , for those who are continuing to work even through terminal illness .

she says that the bank santander has set a `` compassionate example '' in the way it treats people suffering from terminal illness , including freezing her payments and taking them from her estate when she dies .
the bank is also not increasing her interest payments
she asks if other banks should follow this model .
mrs may congratulates santander for the way it has treated her constituent , adding that it is importance for employers to be aware of and deal with the problems facing terminally-ill employees .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: will english fans be safe at russia world cup ? prime minister 's questions
text: labour 's david crausby mentions the world cup , due to be held in russia this june .
the government recently announced that members of the royal family and ministers would not be attending in protest at the salisbury poisoning .
he says this is the right decision and asks `` what is being done to safeguard everyday football fans in what was , in my opinion , already a dangerous place to watch football '' .
he also wants to know what advice there is for travelling england fans and what police cooperation there is between russian and british police .
theresa may says it 's an `` important issue '' and that `` we want english fans to be safe '' .
she says the police are working hard to ensure fans will be safe and the foreign office are `` carefully monitoring the situation '' .
at euro 2016 in france , english fans came under attack within the stadium during a game against russia .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: a matter of survivalprime minister 's questions
text: concern about the fisheries deal from the conservative benches - this is a matter of survival for a number of conservative mps .
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: fisheries arrangement 'worst imaginable'prime minister 's questions
text: the snp 's drew hendry says the fisheries arrangement reached with the eu leaves the uk with `` no say - the worst deal imaginable '' .
mrs may pledges to work with fishing communities to `` ensure we do see a bright future '' and ensure they are not denied access to waters .
she undertakes to `` rebuild our fishing industry '' .
she points out the snp wanted to stay in the common fisheries policy .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: university vice-chancellor pay questionedprime minister 's questions
text: conservative michelle donelan says that the education committee - of which she is a member - has recently interviewed university vice-chancellors .
they have no idea how high their pay really is , she states , with some earning a salary that is double that of the prime minister .
she asks if the post-18 education review will look at these issues .
mrs may says it is an issue that many people are concerned about .

universities are independent of government , she adds , but the office for students will create more transparency and `` shine a light '' on staff pay and will look at the value for money students receive at such institutions .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour mp presses pm over aid to eastern ghoutaprime minister 's questions
text: labour 's louise ellman asks what the government is doing to ensure humanitarian relief reaches people in the syrian region of the eastern ghouta .
theresa may replies that the government is taking the issue `` very seriously indeed '' .
ministers have been `` very clear '' about what needs to happen for humanitarian aid to get into the region and will `` '' continue to press this case '' , replies theresa may .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: portsmouth schools 'starved ' of moneyprime minister 's questions
text: labour 's stephen morgan says that there have been £ 3.3m of cuts to schools in portsmouth which are being `` starved of resources '' .
he also says that 40,000 children are reliant on food banks to eat .
he asks the pm what , if she was a teacher , she would `` buy a struggling child - a textbook or a square meal ? ''
theresa may says the amount of money being spent on schools is `` greater than it has ever been before '' .
but she says `` what matters is the quality of education '' and that in portsmouth there are 9,000 more people at outstanding schools than in 2010 .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: may calls cambridge analytica allegations 'very concerning'prime minister 's questions
text: snp leader at westminster ian blackford asks the pm if she agrees `` subverting the democratic political process is unacceptable '' and she says it 's something `` everyone in the house would accept '' .
he refers to former conservative figures who have played a role in cambridge analytica , claiming : `` their links to conservative party go on and on . ''
theresa may specifies there are `` no current contracts '' between her party and ca or its parent company scl .
she calls the allegations `` very concerning '' and says it 's right that the ico is investigating .
she urges ca and facebook to comply .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: fully recyclable coffee cups in corby - mpprime minister 's questions
text: conservative tom pursglove says that worldwide , millions of paper coffee cups are thrown away every minute .
he says that a company in his constituency has developed a fully recyclable coffee cup and he asks if she will congratulate the company on this innovation .
mrs may says that she would be happy to get one of these coffee cups , adding that the government are keen to leave the environment in a better place than the way they found it .
the government has been clear in their 25 year plan about how they intend to deal with waste , she states .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pm lauds 'balanced approach ' to spendingprime minister 's questions
text: jeremy corbyn uses his final question to say that half a million businesses will see business rates rise this year .
the government , he says , has `` slashed public services '' and is expecting councils to `` up the pieces '' of lower funding .
the government 's model is `` pay more to get less '' , he adds .
in response theresa may says the government is spending more on schools and hospitals that `` than ever before '' - only possible because of a `` balanced approach '' to spending .
she also up on today 's unemployment figures , which she says show joblessness falling to its lowest level since 1975 .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: government 'tearing heart out ' of high streetsprime minister 's questions
text: jeremy corbyn says `` labour councils build houses , conservative councils privatise '' .
he rounds on the government for a rise in rates of £ 3,600 for small shops .
he says that `` empty shops suck the life out of our high streets and local communities '' and asks why the government is `` tearing the heart out '' of high streets .
theresa may replies by mentioning the defection of two labour councilors in ashfield to the tories .
she quotes one of them saying labour had been `` taken over by the hard left '' who were `` more interested in fighting internal ideological battles '' .
she says the tories always welcome `` people who will stand up for people in their local area '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: raucous pre-local election exchangesprime minister 's questions
text: raucous pre-local election exchanges .
theresa may seemed a bit stumbling at first but then regained her footing .
jeremy corbyn raises examples of local cuts .
charge and counter charge fly back and forth .
but is anyone the wiser at the end ?
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: corbyn and may clash on council taxprime minister 's questions
text: jeremy corbyn cites comments by surrey county council leader that councils are facing `` the most difficult financial crisis in our history '' and says council funding has been cut by half since 2010 at the same time as england faces tax rises .
he claims it shows under the conservatives you `` pay more to get less '' .
theresa may says council tax is on average £ 100 less under the conservatives than under labour .

she says labour leaders in haringey , brighton and cornwall were forced out for `` supporting building more homes and tackling anti-semitism '' and people who do this are told there 's `` no place for you in the labour party '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'northamptonshire has gone bust ' - corbynprime minister 's questions
text: jeremy corbyn says that `` northamptonshire has gone bust , '' blaming the government and the council .
he says that barnet council outsourced to capita with an estimated £ 500m contract and has now has cut services .
mr corbyn says that councils now face a £ 5.2bn funding gap by 2020 .
he asks if the government should have prioritised tax cuts for `` the super rich and big business , '' over social care , potholes , bin collection , libraries or street cleaning .
mrs may replies that in birmingham the council has failed to collect bins , adding that it is a labour run council .
she adds that the top percentage of earners are paying more than they did under labour .
she says that the shadow local government secretary , andrew gwynne , has said that local councils should n't have the power to stop council tax rises .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: corbyn criticises 'slash and burn ' modelprime minister 's questions
text: jeremy corbyn replies that the tory leader of northamptonshire council had warned the government back in 2013/14 that it could not cope with the scale of cuts .
he says the council put in place a `` slash and burn '' model which involved outsourcing 96 % of its staff to private firms .
theresa may says a recent statutory report said the financial crisis in the county was `` not a case of under funding '' .
the government is ensuring councils up and down the country can provide good services and are `` costing people less '' than would be the case under labour .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: leaders clash over council failureprime minister 's questions
text: leader of the opposition jeremy corbyn joins the pm 's tributes to those killed in the attack on westminster a year ago tomorrow , and to the red arrows engineer who died yesterday at raf valley .
he asks if the `` collapse '' of northamptonshire council is due to `` conservative incompetence at a local level , or conservative incompetence at a national level ? ''
theresa may replies by saying that we should `` look at what we see across the board '' to cheers from her backbenches .
`` conservative councils cost you less '' , she says .
`` my question was quite specific '' says mr corbyn .
he says the tory leader of northants council had been warning the government they could n't cope with the scale of cuts since 2014 .

theresa may says it `` would be helpful if he accurately reflected '' the conclusions of a report into the council , that she says said `` northamptonshire 's failure is not a case of underfunding '' .

`` the attack that he is making , that this is all about the amount of money the government is providing is not correct '' she says , `` we are ensuring that councils are able to provide good service up and down the country '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: may hails brexit trade opportunitiesprime minister 's questions
text: conservative gareth johnson says as part of the eu the uk 's ability to trade with the rest of the world has been `` curtailed for over 40 years '' and trade `` is brexit 's greatest opportunity '' .
theresa may agrees with him , noting `` we will be able to forge our own way by signing deals with old friends and new allies '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: pmqs gets under wayprime minister 's questions
text: first question today comes from labour 's george howarth .
he says that since 2010 , merseyside police has lost 1084 police officers and crime has gone up by 18.5 % .
mrs may says tomorrow marks the one year anniversary of the westminster terror attack .
she pays tribute to the `` exceptional bravery '' of the police and security services .
she also expresses condolences to the raf engineer who died in an raf crash yesterday .
she congratulates andria zafirakou on winning the global teacher prize .

answering the question , mrs may says that the knowsley safety partnership means that crime statistics have fallen by 9 % since 2010 but as for firearms incidents , she says , police are giving their full attention to these incidents .
she adds that the home secretary is ensuring that £ 450m in extra funding will be available to police forces across the country .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: watch : theresa may opens pmqs by remembering events a year ago
text: `` it was a sick and depraved attack on the streets of our capital '' @ twitterid on the westminster attack 12 months ago on thursday # pmqs

documents.title: assurances offered on limiting henry viii powerseu withdrawal bill
text: a government spokesman lord keen of elie tells the house the delegated powers created in the bill are intended to be `` tightly limited '' .
he says ministers are `` committed to transparency of sis '' and their requirements may be `` expanded to address concerns '' .

but he notes it 's `` not always straightforward what is a protection '' because rights of some protected groups may conflict , and he gives the example of women 's services potentially denying the rights of transgender people .
he promises to `` reflect on what is a constructive suggestion '' and lord low agrees to withdraw his amendment .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: gearing up prime minister 's questions
text: pmqs is a few minutes away and the chamber is filling up .
there 'll be a sudden influx of mps just before noon , when pmqs gets under way .
theresa may has just arrive to cheers from her backbenchers .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour backs stronger equalities requirementseu withdrawal bill
text: labour spokesman lord goldsmith says he agrees with lord low , noting there is `` concern that rights should not be removed '' .

he observes that producing explanatory statements showing how equality requirements are being met is a `` valuable technique '' which places `` a personal obligation on the minister '' to fulfil his or her duties .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: prime minister 's questions : preview
text: it is a target-rich environment at pmqs this week , if not for party leaders , then certainly for backbench mps .

the fast-moving facebook-cambridge analytica story provides one alluring subject for backbenchers , but leaders might be a little more wary unless they are completely satisfied that their organisations have crossed no ethical lines in their own data-mining activities .
then there 's russia and russian oligarchs .

again one imagines some frantic checking of party donors has been going on behind the scenes - so maybe it will be backbench campaigners on human rights and tax transparency who will make the running here .

the announcement of a brexit transitional deal should produce brexiteer congratulations for the pm but the language and tone of tory remainers will bear watching , if any of them decide to raise the subject .
and then there are the mps from fishing constituencies .
remember that it was the tories electoral success in scotland , including several fishing constituencies , that kept them as the biggest party in the commons after their 2017 election debacle .
the mps in those seats fear this deal could signal their doom - so will any of them intervene ?

yesterday the lib dem former scottish secretary alistair carmichael moved fast to fire in an urgent question ( pipping labour 's melanie onn and a scottish conservative - i think it was douglas ross ) and maximise their discomfort .
today the snp 's ian blackford will doubtless seek to stir the pot some more .
and even more interesting pot-stirring may come from the pro-brexit erg , the blandly named but seriously effective european research group , which coordinates the backbench brexiteers .
will their ringmaster , jacob rees mogg repeat the criticism of the government he made on newsnight , last night .
what might jeremy corbyn raise ?
last week labour forced votes on a series of welfare changes , including to free school meals.yesterday the labour peers won a regret motion '' against eligibility changes to free school meals .

they say ministers should now pause the regulations and conduct a full poverty impact assessment , and then return to parliament with a better , targeted package that avoids creating a poverty cliff-edge for poor in-work families .
their leader may make the same point - but if he does , he can expect some serious pushback from tory backbenchers who say labour is simply factually wrong on this issue .

tory backbenchers have also noted that mr corbyn can seem to be , if not rattled , at least disrupted by heckling - and so if the temperature goes up , a mixture of anger and calculation on their part could make for a very rowdy session .
all of which may bounce off theresa may .
in recent pmqs , perhaps buoyed by a bit of brexit progress , she has become more confident .
and now she can trumpet today 's nhs pay deal , and will also be seeking to plug a new announcement on housing and infrastructure spending for new developments .
on the party-political side , the pm will doubtless come armed with sheaves of quotes from labour mps unhappy at their leader 's line on the salisbury poisoning .
her advisers want her to be edgier and more assertive but her counter-attacks have often seemed stilted and over-processed .
is he willing to take more risks this time ?
author: Mark D'Arcy
Parliamentary Correspondent

documents.title: today in the house of commons
text: the day in the commons is under way with northern ireland questions , followed at midday by the weekly showdown of prime minister 's questions .
after pmqs the shadow health secretary jon ashworth has an urgent question on nhs pay , following reports that 1.3m staff are set to get a pay rise .

the main business of the day is two bills on northern ireland , one setting rates and making changes to the renewable heath initiative scheme and another giving the secretary of state for northern ireland the power to adjust pay for members of the northern ireland assembly when it is not sitting .
the uk parliament is currently legislating on northern ireland matters after the power-sharing government collapsed over the botched renewable heat initiative scheme .
an election in march 2017 and subsequent talks between the two biggest parties , the dup and sinn fein , failed to produce a functioning executive .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: disability rights campaigner seeks safeguards for equality protectionseu withdrawal bill
text: peers begin day nine of eleven days of committee-stage debate on the eu withdrawal bill , which repeals the european communities act 1972 and writes eu law into uk law ahead of brexit .
committee stage is when peers carry out detailed line-by-line scrutiny of legislation , but amendments are not normally forced to a vote - this happens at report stage .
crossbencher lord low of dalston is introducing an amendment designed to rule out the use of delegated powers to change equality rights and protections underpinned by eu law .
the bill requires ministers to `` have due regard '' to equal rights protections , but lord low argues there would be nothing to stop them fulfilling this while reducing statutory duties .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: today in the house of lords
text: the house of lords is holding an early sitting today to get through the ninth day of the committee-stage on the eu withdrawal bill .
starting from 11am the main focus of the day will be clause 11 , which deals with how powers returned to westminster would then be returned to the devolved administrations .
nicola sturgeon , first minister of scotland , called the clause a naked power grab '' and it has also attracted criticism from labour and some conservatives .
in the commons - to ward off a rebellion by scottish tory mps - the government promised amendments .
at 2.30pm proceedings on the bill will be interrupted for ministers to take questions from peers on undercover policing , human rights , respite care and gender pay inequality .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: good morning
text: welcome to our live coverage of wednesday in parliament .
the house of lords gets down to work at 11am , earlier than usual , in order to make some progress with the eu withdrawal bill .
it 's day nine of the detailed committee-stage scrutiny of the legislation .
the commons gets under way at 11.30am with northern ireland questions followed by prime minister 's questions at noon .

there 's plenty of action in the committee rooms this afternoon , with boris johnson giving evidence to the foreign affairs committee and former facebook employee , sandy parakilas talking to the culture committee about fake news .

documents.title: breakinggovernment defeated on changes to free school mealsfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: peers vote to back labour 's lord bassam 's motion to regret changes in entitlement to free school meals through the free school lunches and milk , and school and early years finance ( amendments relating to universal credit ) ( england ) regulations 2018 .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: new free school meal system more generous - ministerfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: responding for the government , education minister lord agnew of oulton tells peers the government is committed to `` healthy free school meal for the most disadvantaged '' .
he says the new means test will mean that by 2022 50,000 more children will benefit , and he pledges `` no child will lose a free school meal '' .
he points out that `` it 's simply not true '' to say one million children will lose out , as that 's based on a `` hypothetical scenario '' .
the new system will be more generous , he adds .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: ex-minister questions free school meal changesfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: the motion to regret changes to free school meals is also backed by the labour front bench .

lord bassam gets partial backing from a surprising quarter , as conservative former work and pensions minister and universal credit architect lord freud agrees with him that the changes could be a work disincentive .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peer claims statistics have been misrepresentedfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: conservative lord patten says we must deal in facts not sentiment , and accuses lord bassam of perpetrating a `` statistical tearaway '' on free school meals .
but lib dem , labour and crossbench peers and a bishop all rise to support the motion to regret .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: children will 'pay the price ' for school dinner changesfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: lib dem education spokesman lord storey says we need to think about `` children who most need our support , children who are living in poverty and who are not well-fed '' .
he recalls teaching children for whom `` a holiday from school is a holiday from hot dinners '' , warning it will be them who `` pay the price of our meanness '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peer moves to oppose changes to free school mealsfree school lunches : motion to regret
text: labour 's lord bassam of brighton is introducing a motion to regret changes in entitlement to free school meals through the free school lunches and milk , and school and early years finance ( amendments relating to universal credit ) ( england ) regulations 2018 .

the government plans to establish a means test so that if parents are on universal credit and earning more than £ 7,400 from work , their children will no longer be entitled to free school meals if they 're in year 3 or above .
lord bassam argues this will `` undermine work incentives '' in universal credit and `` leave up to a million poor children unable to claim free school meals '' .
he is calling on the government not to implement the regulations until a full poverty impact assessment has been completed and considered by both houses .
he recalls his own experience of entitlement to free lunches as a child , which meant he got `` a hot meal five days a week without my mum having to worry '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers seek guarantees on nuclear it systemsnuclear safeguards bill
text: peers are now interrogating how the government on a lib dem-led amendment to require reporting on it systems to support nuclear safeguards after brexit .
energy minister lord henley says he understands the need for `` substantive reassurances '' but there are requirements for reporting on the face of the bill .
the bill passes report stage shortly afterwards and will progress to third reading .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: breakinggovernment defeated on review of relationship with euratomnuclear safeguards bill
text: peers vote 244 to 194 for labour 's amendment , which would require independent reporting on future arrangements with euratom , including information relating to nuclear research and development and the import and export of qualifying nuclear material .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: vote on independent review of relationship with euratomnuclear safeguards bill
text: lord hunt is not convinced by the minister 's response and forces a vote on labour 's amendment , which would require independent reporting on future arrangements with euratom , including information relating to nuclear research and development and the import and export of qualifying nuclear material .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: government seeking 'ambitious ' agreement on nuclear materialsnuclear safeguards bill
text: business , energy and industrial strategy minister lord henley says that he has visited sellafield , which he says will be one of the sites affected by new nuclear safeguarding rules .
in 2017 , the government guaranteed its share of funding for the oxfordshire reactor , subject to the eu also continuing with funds for the project .
he says this is independent of the outcome of brexit .
the government continues to work closely with relevant nuclear bodies , especially for the best way forward for the nuclear sector after the uk leaves the eu , he says .
the government recognises the continued importance of import and export of nuclear trade in goods , and the government is seeking a `` bold and ambitious '' new agreement for such matters , he adds .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: cooper 'very concerned ' at lack of torture victim figureshome affairs committee
text: committee chair yvette cooper asks the panel how many of the people they detain are victims of torture , but does n't get an answer from any of the four members of the panel .
the panellists from serco say that if their staff have been told by a detainee that they are a victim of torture that will be recorded , but they have no centralised figure .
phil wragg of the prisons service says there is a figure recorded but neither he nor morton hall manager karen head know what it is .
`` this would seem like one of the most important things to know '' says yvette cooper .
`` i am very concerned that you do n't know those figures , or even know roughly what proportion of those people who you have in detention are victims of torture '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: labour calls for reporting on future relationship with euratomnuclear safeguards bill
text: labour spokesman lord hunt of kings heath speaks to an amendment which would require the government to report on future arrangements with euratom - specifically research and development - and the import and export of nuclear material .
he says the uk is `` being given these responsibilities to police '' and `` having as a backstop an independent reviewer would be an important safeguard '' .
the proposal is also backed by the lib dems .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'majority ' of morton hall incidents 'low-level self harm'home affairs committee
text: morton hall immigration removal centre manager karen head says that since the deaths at the centre last year , the `` majority of our incidents are low-level self harm , not to minimise that '' .
she adds : `` we did have a man who did make an attempt at a ligature within the last three months and had to be treated on site '' .
she says of the four deaths last year at the centre , two have been confirmed as suicides , with two still to go to inquest .
the four deaths at the centre were carlington spencer , 38 , from jamaica ; lukasz debowski , 27 , from poland ; bal ahmed kabia , 49 , from sierra leone and a 27-year-old iraqi man .
the centre , south of lincoln , is for people who are waiting to be removed from the uk , some of whom are being deported following prison sentences .
it has space for 392 detainees and is run by the prison service .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: host 'betrayed ' over cancer sick pay
text: host 'betrayed ' over cancer sick pay

documents.title: government has taken an important step - ministernorthern ireland budget bill
text: northern ireland minister shailesh vara says the government has taken an important step in agreeing budgets for the coming year .
the funds to be used are for resources only , he says , no recommendations were made by the assembly before it collapsed on how money should be spent .
the spending allocations include any funding for brexit costs , he states .
he adds that until recently there were talks aimed at re-forming the assembly but the decision was eventually made to produce a budget from westminster instead .
the bill confirms departmental allocations for the coming year as well as revised allocations .
the minister says it is a technical bill about `` formalising '' allocations for northern ireland departments .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: house having to discuss 'things we really should n't have to be discussing ' - labournorthern ireland budget bill
text: shadow northern ireland office minister stephen pound says he has `` an enormous amount of sympathy '' for the northern ireland secretary karen bradley .
he feels the commons has had to discuss `` things that we really should n't have to be discussing '' such as keeping the heating and lights on .
ultimately , he says , this is a subject that no-one really wants to have to address in the commons .
he has heard there are `` important '' housing issues in northern ireland but , he says , these are the problems the northern irish government should be working on .
`` we have a duty to be evangelical and optimistic , '' he says , `` they deserve the best [ in northern ireland ] . ''
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: breakinggovernment defeated on withdrawal from euratomnuclear safeguards bill
text: peers vote 265 to 194 in favour of crossbencher lord broers ' amendment , which allows for the suspension of withdrawal from euratom if appropriate international agreements have not been reached by exit day .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: serco rejects claims of widespread hunger strike at yarl 's woodhome affairs committee
text: serco 's julia rogers says that at yarl 's wood `` no-one on hunger strike at the moment '' but there are `` a number of people who routinely will miss a meal '' .

she says that `` a maximum '' of 81 people were `` not attending for all three meals '' but says that there were only five people who were neither going to the dining room , nor buying food from the shop .
she says serco has the data to prove this .
she says that the people hunger striking were `` very clear to us that the reasons for their protest were not to do with serco , but to do with policy '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: vote on withdrawal from euratomnuclear safeguards bill
text: lord broers is not persuaded by the minister and forces a vote on his amendment , which allows for the suspension of withdrawal from euratom if appropriate international agreements have not been reached by exit day .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: mps quiz immigration centre officialshome affairs committee
text: the committee is now hearing from officials responsible for the running of morton hall and yarl 's wood immigration detention centres .
morton hall is run by the prison service , while yarl 's wood is run by the outsourcing firm serco .
appearing in front of the committee are :
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: leaving euratom is 'a done deal ' - ministernuclear safeguards bill
text: energy minister lord henley resists the amendment , arguing it would cause `` confusion and doubt '' .
notification of leaving euratom has `` already been debated at length and accepted by the eu '' , he continues , `` it 's a done deal '' .
he assures peers `` good progress '' has been made in talks with the european union and the international atomic energy agency to achieve `` smooth '' withdrawal from euratom .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: lord hutton : failing to reach nuclear agreements 'a major problem'nuclear safeguards bill
text: labour 's lord hutton of furness , chairman of the nuclear industries association warns peers they need to `` pay attention to the risk we have not renegotiated '' the necessary agreements by the time we leave the eu .
this would be `` a very major problem '' , he says , making it `` impossible for us to continue legally and lawfully '' to exchange nuclear materials .
the amendment on pausing euratom withdrawal is also backed by the labour front bench .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: immigration detention doctors in 'difficult position'home affairs committee
text: the committee is discussing mental health in immigration removal centres .

tom nunn of bail for immigration detainees says doctors are put into a difficult position when attempting to provide mental health care for those in detention because many of the worst mental health problems are caused by the lack of certainty surrounding their detention .
`` often the thing that would make you better would be not being in immigration detention '' , he says .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: 'a lot of people being forgotten ' at immigration detention centreshome affairs committee
text: the committee is looking into immigration removal centres following four deaths last year at morton hall in lincolnshire .
the centre houses people awaiting their asylum decisions as well as failed asylum seekers waiting to be removed from the country .
the committee also wants to know more about yarl 's wood , where a hunger strike is underway .
kris harris of medical justice says it 's a `` red herring to focus on the issues in one centre '' .
tom nunn , who works offering legal advice says he notes a `` desperation '' whenever he visits yarl 's wood but also `` a lot of solidarity amongst the women '' .
as for morton hall , he calls it a place where `` a lot of people are being forgotten '' .
gemma lousley of the group women for refugee women says that at yarl 's wood , a centre for women detainees , she finds `` insecurity and instability '' when she visits .
she adds that when surveyed `` almost half of the women there felt unsafe '' because of `` not knowing when they might be released , not knowing what was going to happen to them ultimately '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: upside to leaving euratom ? nuclear safeguards bill
text: conservative viscount trenchard suggests there could be an `` upside to leaving euratom '' .
he submits that we may `` do better to have our own safeguard regime '' outside the `` onerous and cumbersome process '' of the eu-wide framework .
the uk 's security could be enhanced if we are not obliged to share all research and development in this area , he adds .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: we stand ready to get back into government - dupnorthern ireland budget bill
text: dup westminster leader nigel dodds says he empathises with sammy wilson in his frustration at getting answers in these debates .
he welcomes the fact that the northern ireland secretary , karen bradley , is bringing the budget to the house .
mr dodds jokes that there does n't appear to be any division among mps sitting in the commons on making decisions about northern ireland in westminster .
his point is that the northern irish border is being used by some mps to `` thwart brexit '' or to shape it for their own ends .
he accuses sinn fein of refusing to work on particularly difficult issues .
and says the dup `` stand ready to get back into the government immediately '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peer seeks option to suspend euratom withdrawalnuclear safeguards bill
text: crossbencher lord broers is introducing an amendment to ensure that if the relevant international agreements are not in place by 1st march 2019 , the uk government must request to suspend the uk 's withdrawal from euratom .

the suspension would apply until either agreements are in place , or other arrangements have been made to allow the uk to continue with existing safeguard arrangements until the relevant agreements are in place .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers resume scrutiny of post-brexit nuclear safeguardsnuclear safeguards bill
text: peers are now getting started on report stage of the nuclear safeguards bill , which enables the government to set up a domestic nuclear safeguards regime , replacing the current framework provided principally by membership of the european atomic energy community ( euratom ) .

nuclear safeguards arrangements enable the united kingdom to meet international nuclear safeguards standards and engage in certain international civil nuclear activities , including trade and research and development .
report stage is when changes discussed earlier in the bill 's passage are usually made - either through amendments brought forward by the government or forced on them through a vote .
energy minister lord henley introduces an amendment to define the meaning of `` civil activities '' within the bill , in order to narrow the scope of delegated powers arising from this legislation .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: labour and lib dems slam fisheries arrangement with eufisheries statement
text: shadow environment spokesperson baroness jones of whitchurch accuses the environment secretary michael gove of making `` great play '' of regaining control over fishing waters and `` he has now been overruled '' .
she says the party has `` real concerns '' he 'll be overruled on other issues within cabinet and calls on him to `` be more honest with fishing communities '' .
lib dem baroness bakewell of hardington mandeville tells the chamber the news has prompted `` a great deal of anger and unrest '' after the government `` had promised to take back control '' .

environment minister lord gardiner stresses the uk share of quotas will not change and the focus will be on `` advancing the things we think absolutely right '' during the transition period , such as ensuring waters are sustainably fished .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: mps investigating immigration detentionhome affairs committee
text: the home affairs committee is holding an evidence session on immigration detention centres .
the session comes amid a hunger strike at yarl 's wood detention centre by women detained there .
the government came under fire earlier this month for sending letters to detainees telling them participation in the hunger strike may speed up their deportation .
the first set of witnesses in front of the committee are all advocates for people detained in the asylum and detention system :

later this afternoon mps will hear from representatives of serco , the private company that runs yarl 's wood , hm prisons and probation service , and the manager of morton hall , another immigration detention centre in lincolnshire .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: dup : time for 'important , political step'northern ireland budget bill
text: the dups ' sammy wilson says some mps do understand what the legislation is actually about .
and he suggests that the bill has its limits .

`` simply giving departments ( in northern ireland ) the information about the amount of money they are going to have does not give them the ability to spend the money , '' he says , `` because there are some things civil servants are going to need direction about . ''

he says the northern ireland secretary karen bradley has `` taken the first step '' but the `` big , important political step '' - in the absence of the northern ireland assembly - is to create a mechanism whereby decisions about spending `` can be made politically '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peers hear fisheries updatefisheries statement
text: environment minister lord gardiner of kimble is repeating an answer to an urgent question asked earlier in the commons by lib dem alistair carmichael on fisheries management arrangements after the uk leaves the eu .
the environment secretary , michael gove , expressed `` disappointment '' that the uk will not regain full control over the country 's fishing waters on brexit day , 29 march 2019 .
the uk will regain full control for the first time in 40 years after december 2020 , he insisted .
he urged fishing communities to keep their `` eyes on the prize '' of getting control .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: snp : bill to 'keep the lights on'northern ireland budget bill
text: the snp 's northern ireland spokesperson , deidre brock , says she deplores the fact that the devolved institutions at stormont are `` still in suspended animation '' , calling it `` a disgrace '' .
she says she hopes it will be the last budget for northern ireland set at westminster .
and she urges all parties to approve the bill `` for the sake of keeping the lights and the heating on '' in northern ireland .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: tory peer : make children up litteroral questions
text: conservative lord robathan asks the government to consider including litter in the national curriculum for year 6 children , to tidy up the roads and encourage civic responsibility .
he tells peers : `` the shocking and disgusting proliferation of litter shames this nation . ''

education minister lord agnew of oulton replies that children are taught about scientific concepts relating to the environment and schools are working actively to involve them in environmental schemes .
labour 's lord winston says it 's better to focus on literacy and numeracy , but the minister responds that children 's attitude to littering is connected to their `` respect for our society '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: allow medical abortions at home , urges labour peeroral questions
text: crossbencher baroness watkins of tavistock asks why there are no plans to enable women undergoing early medical abortion to take the second dose of the medication , misoprostol , at home , if they so wish .
she argues women should be able to `` choose the dignity of being as comfortable as possible '' , and this is particularly a factor for women in rural areas .
health minister lord o'shaughnessy says the priority is to ensure `` safe , high-quality care '' under the terms of the 1967 abortion act .
there 's no time frame for a policy change , he adds .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: labour indicates support for budget billnorthern ireland budget bill
text: the shadow northern ireland secretary owen smith says labour will be supporting the bill .
he mentions that today marks the 25th anniversary of the warrington bombing , where two boys were killed by an ira bomb .
he says the commemorations in the town today should be a reminder of how far northern ireland has come .

he raises a few questions about the budget itself , as well as raising concerns at the fact that civil servants in belfast are now making decisions that should be taken by their absent political masters .
`` we can all see that that 's not a situation we 'd wish to place civil servants in , and it 's not one that can continue indefinitely '' , he says .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: cash for conservative-dup dealparliamentary reporter tweets
text: northern ireland budget ( anticipation and adjustments ) bill allocates £ 410m in financial support arising from the financial annex to the confidence and supply agreement between the conservative party and the democratic unionist party '' .
nothing for the child abuse victims of the hia inquiry as they are left to suffer and die 1by1 , this shame of the ni plastic goverment and uk goverment , shame on you all
# cambridgeanalyticauncovered
# cambridgeanalyticauncovered

documents.title: labour hails lord richard 's statesmanship
text: shadow lords leader baroness smith of basildon says peers will miss lord richard 's `` wisdom , expertise and statesmanship '' .
she pays tribute to his role in lords reform and welsh devolution , describing his contribution to parliament as `` huge '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers pay tribute to lord richard
text: peers are beginning their day with tributes to former labour leader of the lords , lord richard of ammanford , who has died aged 85 .
he called for more powers and ams for the welsh assembly in a 2004 report for the welsh government .
born in betws , carmarthenshire , ivor richard was mp for barons court in london from 1964 to 1974 .
he was british ambassador to the united nations from 1974 to 1979 and a european commissioner from 1981 to 1985 , before being made a peer in 1990 .
the current lords leader , baroness evans of bowes park , describes him as a `` significant figure '' who displayed a `` fearsome combination of intellect and passion '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: mps debate northern ireland budget billnorthern ireland budget bill
text: mps are now debating the northern ireland budget ( anticipation and adjustments ) bill , which provides for day-to-day spending in the run up to the estimates process for northern ireland .
northern ireland has been without devolved government since january 2017 .
northern ireland secretary karen bradley says she has deferred this action until it was absolutely necessary .
action is required now to ensure public services can function , she says .
`` this is not a budget for the year ahead , '' ms bradley says , and does not feature departmental spending allowances .
`` it represents the minimum necessary intervention to secure public finances at this juncture , '' she states .
there is no new money for northern ireland in the bill , she adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: what can the government do about poor governance ? corporate governance statement
text: liberal democrat leader sir vince cable says the minister has announced a `` sensible set of proposals '' but he wonders what the government can do about currently about poor corporate governance .

he cites toys r us , where the managing director was able to - as sir vince puts it - `` loot the company , loading it up with debt , using complex instruments and tax havens , '' leaving behind a legacy of damaged pension funds and redundancies .

business minister andrew griffiths says that when a company is taken over , new owners often put in `` complicated measures '' in order to make sure that they are not harmed by any ill effects from the acquisition .
the powers that have been proposed , he says , would allow the government to recoup that money .
some businesses will always fail , he adds , but the government believes that the measures it is introducing will give shareholders a voice in how businesses are run .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: small business should not 'suffer'corporate governance statement
text: snp 's drew hendry suggests proposals to `` force '' chief executives and company directors to `` engage directly '' with small business .
citing the `` refusal '' of bosses at the royal bank of scotland to meet firms affected by changes made by the bank , he says `` lots of problems could have been avoided '' by engaging with people .
he goes on to say that small businesses `` should not be ones to suffer '' when a large company goes bust .
he wonders what action the government is taking to protect small and medium sized enterprises .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: government is reviewing stance on corporate governancecorporate governance statement
text: business minister andrew griffiths replies that it would be inappropriate for the government to make comments on companies with contracts in the public sector as it could affect their share prices .
directors can be disqualified under current rules for up to 15 years , he states , anyone contravening these disqualifications are committing a criminal offence .
companies paying out dividends as a result of a healthy business is `` something to be applauded , '' mr griffiths states .
the government is reviewing its stance on corporate governance to see what can be done better , he finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour : time for 'action not consultation'corporate governance statement
text: labour 's shadow minister laura pidcock says there were two substantive measures announced in this statement .
she goes on to say there are `` vague '' powers for the insolvency service and how it will respond to cases of business collapse .
it is time is for action not consultation , she says .
she remarks that the government is reviewing the taylor review which was , in itself , a review .
she asks what the government is doing to make sure that companies with public sector contracts - such as interserve - do not collapse .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: minister : uk corporate governance to remain 'envy of the world'corporate governance statement
text: business minister andrew griffiths is making a statement on government plans for a consultation on the uk 's corporate governance framework .
he says they want to ensure that british corporate governance `` remains the envy of the world '' .
he says `` we are determined to learn the lessons from corporate failures such as carillion and reduce the risk of major company failures occurring '' .

the government is consulting on new sanctions against the `` reckless '' selling of companies `` with no regard for their future '' , the possibility of reversing inappropriate asset stripping to pay creditors and stopping directors dissolving companies to avoid debts .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: revised business for tomorrowthe leader of the house tweets
text: @ andrealeadsom 's revised business statement in full :
how on earth are you in the leaders office with a # welfare # voting record as dire as this andrea ?

documents.title: commons to debate pay for mlas in northern ireland tomorrowbusiness statement
text: leader of the house andrea leadsom is making a very short statement on a new piece of commons business .
she announces that tomorrow 's business will now include a further motion on pay for members of the northern ireland assembly , which is currently suspended .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: hoey : did british negotiators care about fishing ? urgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: labour 's kate hoey says she was given `` assurances '' that the uk would leave the common fisheries policy in march next year .
she asks who was involved in negotiating the transition deal , and whether they `` really care about fishing '' .
in response michael gove says british officials `` negotiated incredibly hard '' but encountered `` intransigence '' from the eu side .
he `` wo n't hear a word said against '' officials at his or the brexit department , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: dup : people 'alarmed and concerned'urgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: the dup mp sammy wilson says there will be many people `` who will be alarmed and concerned '' about the agreement .

he asks mr gove for reassurance that , during the transition period , the eu will act in good faith and not try to `` undermine existing fishing communities '' via legislation , directives and rules .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'very badly let down ' - scottish toryurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: conservative john lamont says that he feels `` very badly let down '' by the deal as the uk will not be taking control of its waters as quickly as it had originally hoped .
he asks for assurances that the uk will have control of vessels and waters after the final period .
mr gove says that the disappointment today is balanced by the benefits at the end of the process .
he says he is determined to ensure the very best deal at the end .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: grimsby mp : fishing deal 'a total sell-out'urgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: labour 's melanie onn says that `` the tories are treating this industry as expendable , '' and industry can not revive based on the status quo that has been achieved on the common fisheries policy .
she says her constituents in great grimsby `` will see this as a total sell out '' .
mr gove says that the conservatives do not take the fishing industry as expendable , which is why the government is investing more in fishing research and other opportunities .
`` the idea that we are not investing in their future is simply not true , '' he says .
he repeats his earlier statement that this is worth it for the larger prize at the end of the process .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: snp : transition outcome 'the worst of all worlds'urgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: the snp 's stephen gethins accuses the conservatives of thinking `` it 's always somebody else 's fault '' .
when a conservative government first brought the uk into the common fisheries policy ( cfp ) , scottish fishermen were described as `` expendable '' , he says .
he says that remaining in the cfp but with no say is `` the worst of all worlds '' , and accuses the conservatives of rejecting previous snp plans to increase control over fisheries .
in reply michael gove says the snp `` has raised grievance to an art form '' and has `` a damned cheek '' in accusing the conservatives blaming others .

documents.title: what did we get in return ? urgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: the conservative jacob rees-mogg is `` slightly concerned '' by michael gove 's tone .
and he has a succinct question : `` what did we get in return ? ''
mr gove replies that the `` big prize '' is for the uk to be able to prepare for all the benefits of brexit during the implementation period .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: no way i can 'sell ' this to fishermen - conservativeurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: conservative douglas ross says that there is `` no way '' he can `` sell '' this deal to fishermen in his constituency in scotland `` as anything like a success '' .
he asks for confirmation that full control of fish stocks will be possible in 2020 , adding fishing communities `` need that guarantee '' .
mr gove states that `` across the united kingdom people will be disappointed that the proposal that we sought to ensure would apply for 2019 did not apply . ''
he adds that this is a 12 month additional extension `` in order to secure the greater prize '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: will the uk have 'full control of our waters ' ? - committee chairurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: chair of the environment , food and rural affairs committee neil parish seeks reassurance that on the 1st january 2021 the uk will have `` full control of our waters '' .
mr gove says that from 1st january 2021 the uk will be classified as a fully independent coastal state .
the uk will join the regional fisheries management organisations by december 2020 so that it can negotiate in january 2021 .
all independent coastal states have to be members of this organisation to ensure fishing is permitted as well as protecting the marine coastal environment , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour : government has failed to take back controlurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: speaking for labour holly lynch recalls that the government promised to `` take back control '' whereas the transition agreement will mean the uk will continue to be part of common fisheries policy for the 21- month transition period .
she says : `` it contradicts all other previous government statements '' and she accuses the government of failling to meets its claims .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: carmichael : 'palpable anger ' in fishing communitiesurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: alistair carmichael says `` the mood in the fishing communities today is one of palpable anger '' .
`` this is not what they were promised , '' he says .
mr carmichael says fishing communities are asking whether , if the government can `` let us down '' in the transitional period , `` will they do it again on the final deal '' ,
and he warns michael gove that the conservatives should `` not be complacent '' about fishermen voting tory .
replying , michael gove agrees : `` there is disappointment in fishing communities ''
he adds that his father was a fish merchant , and he `` completely understands '' and `` shares their disappointment '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: fisheries will not change during the implementation period - goveurgent question : fisheries after brexit
text: liberal democrat alistair carmichael is asking an urgent question about the uk 's agreement to keep eu fishing policies during the brexit transition period .
mr gove says : `` we pressed hard during negotiations to secure this outcome and we are disappointed that the eu were not willing to move on this , '' prompting disapproving noise from the commons .
he says the uk 's share of quotas will not change during the implementation period and the uk will be able to sit in on negotiations for fishing quotas in december 2019 .
at that time , the uk will be negotiating quotas for itself for the first time in 40 years , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: winter crisis will extend beyond easter - labourhealth and social care questions
text: shadow health secretary jonathan ashworth says that today there are more warnings that the winter crisis may extend beyond easter .
he asks if the health secretary will apologise for saying , before the winter , that the nhs was better prepared than ever .
health and social care secretary jeremy hunt says that in the last five years funding in wales went up by 7.2 % , in scotland by 11.5 % and in england by 17.3 % .
but mr ashworth counters that infant mortality is rising and that life expectancy is now dropping , adding that the government has been in power for more nearly eight years .
mr hunt says `` really he can do better than that '' , adding that `` the truth is that the nhs has had its most difficult winter in living memory '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: are personal service companies sexist ? digital , culture , media and sport committee
text: this committee hearing has only touched briefly on recent revelations about the gender pay gap at the corporation .
labour 's jo stevens says the lack of benefits for people employed via personal service companies could be sexist , because of a lack of maternity leave .
liz kershaw says that when she had a baby while a freelance back in the 1990s she had to go back to work `` after six weeks because i could n't afford it .
i ca n't describe how hard that was physically , to be separated from a child at that age '' .
kirsty lang says a colleague of hers had two babies while working for the bbc via a psc .
she says she urged her to see a lawyer and challenge the bbc over the lack of rights to maternity leave but in the end her colleague `` did n't have the stomach for it '' .
when someone is employed through a personal service company the company is paid to provide a service , not the presenter directly .
kirsty lang adds : `` if you 're on staff , they do treat you very well . ''
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: watch : kirsty lang on 'worst fears ' coming true
text: presenter kirsty lang says all her 'worst fears ' about going freelance came true .
'not long after i went freelance , my step-daughter died suddenly , i was unable to take bereavement leave . '
@ twitterid
so why did she ?
i 've been self employed for 20+ yrs and would n't have it any other way .
listen to her testimony and you 'll find out .
she had money set aside because she was paying less tax ?
vegan

documents.title: watch : paul lewis criticises bbc pay arrangements
text: presenter paul lewis : ''this is n't the story of well-paid presenters trading through companies to avoid tax .
this is the story of the bbc forcing hundreds of presenters to form companies and treat them as freelancers . '
'no no do n't reduce my tax exposure aunty !
i want to pay more ' .
female employees presumably less keen ?
you 're missing the point .
the bbc did this to reduce their own tax liability and save the corporation money .
they reassured the presenters that it was perfectly above board and complied with legislation and then hung them out to dry when it went tits up .
dont conflate millionaires doing it for their own tax gains with normal individuals cajoled/forced into it for the larger companies benefit its not helpful
note that many of these people are not rich .
it includes local radio presenters .
they are n't rolling in money .
i 'm also aware of agency nurses , supply teachers and cleaners who are caught up in similar situations .
this is n't just about the bbc .
so why wo n't the gov stop loophole of setting up self employed company for 1 person & fix it to be at 5 ppl must b employed .
then a different level criteria for sole traders .
this is far wider than just the bbc .
this practice is widespread across many industries in the uk .
individuals had little to no control over the terms of their contracts or how they were paid , but trusted experts '' to advise them .
set them all up to paye ! !
also make them all pay the full ni stamp ! !
fed up with these well paid tax dodgers !
many of the people told to use these arrangements are not well paid .
i have heard of agency nurses , supply teachers , cleaners , even newly qualified pilots ( you 'd be surprised how little they earn ) .
the employers saved tax , the employer has a moral responsibility to pay .
you are forgetting that all these schemes back to 1999 were legal at the time ! !
hmrc are applying retrospection and making the tax laws open to interpretation so that they can correct mistakes made by them at a later date .
shameful .
there should be no 'grey ' areas !
they are still legal now as far as i know .
