so basically we are getting penalised for 20 yrs tax on someone 's opinion of what is right or wrong not on letter of the law .
will post copy of letter later .
@ twitterid why ca n't people be freelancers

as a very small player i was warned by my accountant about the ir35 rule and being mainly a one client business and percentage of earnings and to @ make sure range of clients how did these ppl escape any understanding of this - they owe it pay up ! !
in my view many have a case against their accountant for not giving such sensible advice .
i assume this is also motivated by the bbc wishing to cow journalists and reporters to toe the bbc party line and not rock the boat ?
this new accountancy dodge rather seems to coincide with bbc 's timidity in face of government and its lack of challenging opinion.staff too scared ?
but they were happy to take the benefits of these schemes .
but now cry they were duped by the bbc .
crocodile tears methinks .
they should pay their dues .
and certainly not be compensated by the licence payer .
no that does n't appear to be the case at all .
enlighten me .
absolute rubbish .
the presenters have set up ltd companies and their auditors will have warned them of the risks .
they deserve the demands .
have the management @ twitterid been fired for this shameless attempt to evade tax payment to hmrc ?
and hundreds of other umbrella companies doing the same to tens of thousands of ordinary workers .

documents.title: effect of brexit on healthcarehealth and social care questions
text: the snp 's chris law asks what affect brexit will have on the health and social care sector .
health and social care secretary jeremy hunt says that all policy teams in his department continue to explore all scenarios for brexit .
mr law asks how work with european colleagues and institutions will be protected in an academic context .
mr hunt replies that the uk wants to integrate very closely with european structures on medicines research .
he adds that it is a very good opportunity to strengthen the uk 's international research networks , as well as those the uk enjoys with the eu .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: how satisfied are the public with the health and social care system ? health and social care questions
text: labour 's dan carden asks what assessment the government has made of public satisfaction with the social care system .

health and social care minister caroline dinenage says over the last three years , around 65 % of social care users have said they are extremely satisfied with social care support in england with 81 % of adult social care providers rated as good or outstanding .
but mr carden says liverpool city council has faced a 64 % cut in funding for services since 2010 .
the uk needs integrated health and social care , he states , but `` a departmental name change simply wo n't do it . ''
ms dinenage says the integration of adult social care and health services is `` absolutely vital '' .
she states that the government changing the name of the department shows how seriously it takes the matter .
she adds that liverpool is raising £ 7.4m from the social care precept and has received £ 21m in grant funding from the government .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour mp : bbc a 'bullying employer'digital , culture , media and sport committee
text: labour mp julie elliott says she thinks `` what we 're hearing here is a bullying employer '' .
she goes on to suggest that the bbc has exploited the fact that many of their presenters lack a trade union to represent them .
she asks if presenters with personal service companies get any help with tax problems with hmrc .
paul lewis says `` not really no '' and adds that many presenters `` do n't have a clue what their take home will be , and that 's causing real hardship '' .
liz kershaw says some people in the group for presenters they 've formed find they 've been paid nothing at all some months .
front row presenter kirsty lang says in terms of support from the corporation it `` feels like we 've been outsourced which would seem strange to listeners '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: nhs subsidiaries in the spotlighthealth and social care questions
text: justin madders , the shadow health minister , asks the government to rule out the possibility that subsidiaries set up by nhs providers could be privatised .
it follows a question from labour 's eleanor smith about staff morale working for such subsidiaries .
she says they are are often set up to introduce new members of staff to the nhs under worse pay conditions .
health minister stephen barclay replies that nhs providers has said subsidiaries are not going to be used to reduce vat receipts or privatise services .
and he attacks labour for introducing rules in 2006 which allowed the nhs to create its own subsidiaries .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: are we meeting the challenges from an ageing population ? health and social care questions
text: health and social care questions in the commons is under way and conservative richard graham asks what is being done to ensure that primary care services meet the demands of an ageing population .
health and social care secretary jeremy hunt says that by 2020 investment in general practice will have risen by £ 2.4bn , a 14 % increase in real terms .
this includes an additional £ 680m for infrastructure and premises in the last two years .
mr graham says that his local hospital - the gloucestershire royal hospital - has been placed 15th out of 137 hospitals for its a & e performance , despite winter pressure , he adds .
he says that is down to all staff cooperating with other services .
he goes on to say that it is important to let hospitals know that new capital expenditure is available for funding beds and other requirements associated with an ageing population .
mr hunt says that the gloucestershire royal hospital has seen a 10 % improvement in performance year on year .
he adds that his local area has made a capital bid for such services .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: employment test 'at heart ' of many problemsdigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: conservative mp julian knight asks the panel how effectively they thought the bbc has handled investigations by hmrc into presenters ' contracts .
paul lewis says a self-check test to help people work out their employment status is `` at the heart '' of some of the problems .
`` many advisers think it excludes a lot of things , '' he adds .
the latest information he has is that the problem is `` being looked at '' , he says .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: presenter : i tried to hang myself over 'stress ' of pay schemedigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: alongside today 's hearing the committee has published a series of personal statements written by bbc presenters .
as paul lewis said earlier in the hearing , the presenters are at pains to emphasise that moving to a personal service company pay structure was not a way of avoiding tax .

one writes that they have lost out on `` more than £ 400,000 in pension contributions , holiday and sick pay '' because of the scheme , while another says they 've spent `` in excess of £ 10,000 in accountancy fees '' alongside a five figure tax demand .
an anonymous female presenter in local radio says her male co-host is paid £ 4,000 a year more and is , unlike her , entitled to five weeks of paid holiday a year .
she says the `` clawback '' of taxes and the `` stress '' of working for the bbc is `` one of the factors '' that `` took me into my loft where i tried to hang myself '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: 'nobody to go to ' for presentersdigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: liz kershaw intervenes to say that presenters need a `` kind of presenters ' guru '' who can help them with personnel issues .
human resources `` do n't want to know '' and it 's no good speaking to programme producers , she says .
`` there is nobody to go to , '' she says .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: 'i feel like i 've been hung out to dry'digital , culture , media and sport committee
text: kirsty lang goes on to say that she entered into the personal service company arrangements `` in good faith '' and she `` trusted the bbc '' .
`` i feel like i 've been hung out to dry , i feel betrayed , '' she adds .
she has seen `` many '' women presenters `` deprived of maternity leave '' and many colleagues `` deprived of sick pay '' , she tells the committee .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: what 's happening today in the commons ? coming up
text: shortly , the commons will begin its day , starting with health and social care questions at 11.30am .
that 's follow by an urgent question on the management of fisheries after brexit .
at around 1:30pm there will be two statements , one on 'revised ' commons business and one on corporate governance
the main debate today is on the northern ireland budget , which is expected to reduce the pay for members of the legislative assembly until stormont resumes sitting .
finally , labour 's jim mcmahon has an adjournment debate on expanding the metrolink in greater manchester .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'worst fears came true ' after going freelance - kirsty langdigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: kirsty lang says that she was asked to leave her staff job when she requested to go part-time so she could not work as many evenings .
she tells mps she was told that if she was just employed to present a programme on radio 4 , then `` that 's freelance '' .
she was told that `` everyone else '' had set up a personal service company and `` that 's how they were paid '' .
she felt that she `` did n't have a choice '' because she wanted to spend more time with her family , she tells the committee .
after she went freelance all her `` worst fears came true '' - including not being able to take bereavement leave after the sudden death of her step-daughter .
two years after that , she got cancer and worked throughout her treatment , only taking one month off at the end of her chemotherapy course , she says .
she wants to `` make clear '' that she was probably making less money , not more , whilst being paid through the personal service company .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: presenters 'trusted the bbc'digital , culture , media and sport committee
text: stuart linnell , who works for bbc radio northampton , reads from a letter sent to him by the bbc in 2009 which says , if he wants a further contract with the corporation , he will `` be required to have a limited company as this is the policy we are seeking from all our presenters '' .
he says the `` key thing '' is that presenters `` trusted the bbc , the last thing they expected was to find themselves in this situation '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: liz kershaw : i worked for six months without a contractdigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: liz kershaw goes on to say that after radio 6 was not closed down , she had to `` go through the same old rigmarole again '' .
the bbc told her she would have to set up a personal service company for payment or she could n't be engaged as a presenter for a `` regular show '' , she says .
after she refused , her contract ran out at the end of march 2012 and she went until august without having a contract , pay or legal status .
`` i just kept going in every saturday and doing my show and nobody seemed to notice '' , she says .
`` the people on the shop floor did n't know anything about what was going on '' , she adds .
she was later paid for the shifts , she says , but only after presenting an invoice to the corporation .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: presenter : bbc told me arrangement was a tax 'stipulation'digital , culture , media and sport committee
text: committee chair damian collins asks radio 6 presenter liz kershaw whether she was `` coerced into signing documents '' to be paid via a personal service company .

`` i was initially '' , she says - adding that she was initially working as a self-employed freelancer when in late 2009 she received a letter from the bbc that she `` could n't continue like that '' .
the letter , she says , informed her that she would `` have to set up a company '' .
in later email exchanges the bbc claimed this was a `` stipulation '' from hmrc , she tells mps .
having initially said she was n't going to do it , she later then `` gave in '' and set up a company between april 2010 and march 2012 .
this was done because of threats at the time that radio 6 would be closed down , so she could `` make sure i was still gainfully employed '' , she adds .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: 'if you did n't do it , you would n't work'culture committee inquiry : bbc pay
text: chair damian collins asks paul lewis if he was ever paid via a personal service company for his work on money box .
`` i just said i would n't under any circumstances form one '' , he replies .
damian collins asks if anyone was `` compelled '' to do so .
paul lewis says `` the bbc 's point of view is that no-one was forced , but the evidence was that if you did n't do it , you would n't work '' .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: presenters paid through companies to give 'flexibility'culture committee inquiry : bbc pay
text: money box presenter paul lewis says that the story under discussion today is n't about well paid tv stars `` trading through companies to avoid tax '' .
he says the story is about the bbc `` forcing hundreds of presenters to form companies and treat them as freelancers , because that gave the bbc flexibility '' .
he quotes from a bbc press release that says the system `` protected licence fee payers '' .
he says that until last year if hmrc decided someone was `` wrongly classified as a freelance the bbc was n't liable for that error , it was the presenter '' .

this had the effect of allowing the bbc to pay less national insurance which `` probably saved it millions of pounds a year '' with additional savings on other costs of employment like pensions and holiday pay .
additionally , they could `` get rid of any of us on a whim '' .
he says that the risk was that one day hmrc would come to presenters , decide they were wrongly classified , and demand more tax .
he says that the law changed in april last year to make the bbc liable in such a situation and the bbc has now acted to change the status of 90 % of presenters paid through pscs .
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: pay structures under scrutinydigital , culture , media and sport committee
text: the culture committee is hearing from bbc presenters on pay at the corporation .
this part of the committee 's inquiry is focusing on the use of personal service companies .
earlier this year the former presenter of look north , christa ackroyd , was handed a tax bill of £ 420,000 for her use of a psc while working for the bbc between 2001 and 2013 .
she says the bbc encouraged her to sub-contract her work to her personal service company .
the bbc says use of psc 's is `` common '' across the media industry .
appearing in front of the committee today are :
author: Select Committee
Parliament

documents.title: good morning
text: welcome to our live coverage of tuesday in parliament .
we 'll be kicking things off shortly with a culture committee investigation into pay arrangements at the bbc .
the commons chamber gets under way at 11.30am with questions to the health and social care secretary jeremy hunt and his team of ministers .
the house of lords starts work at 2.30pm - peers had a late night last night , debating the eu withdrawal bill

documents.title: summary : monday in parliament
text: the chair of the culture committee , damian collins , secured an urgent question about alleged data breaches at facebook involving the data analysis firm cambridge analytica .
it followed claims in the guardian that cambridge analytica has been conducting political profiling with information harvested from facebook without the account-holders ' consent .
culture secretary matthew hancock called the breach `` very worrying '' and condemned facebook for suspending the account of the whistleblower , christopher wylie .
in other news , it was standing room only for a westminster hall debate on funding for orkambi , a treatment for cystic fibrosis .
dozens of mps made the case for the nhs to pay for the drug , citing some moving case studies from their constituencies .
health minister steve brine said conversations between the government and the manufacturer , vertex , were progressing .

documents.title: peers seek public health guaranteeseu withdrawal bill
text: peers are now discussing proposals for requiring a minister or a public authority to ensure a high level of human health protection is sought in the definition and implementation of all policies and activities .
the lords will continue their debate on the eu withdrawal bill late into the night - but that 's where we have to leave our live page coverage for now .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: all parts of wales will benefit from growth deals - ministerwelsh affairs debate
text: wales office minister stuart andrew says that the importance of using the welsh language , `` even if we stumble and make mistakes '' can not be ignored , echoing earlier comments from liz saville roberts of plaid cymru .
the government is committed to making sure that all parts of wales benefit from growth deals and continued investment , he says .

the government has a universal service obligation in force for wales which will start improving broadband in rural areas of the country , he adds , and the removal of tolls from the severn bridge will help economic growth and encourage people to cross borders .

the wales secretary has recently met with the uk trade commissioner to the united states in order to discuss the ongoing tariff problems which will blight the uk steel industry on imports to the us , he tells mps .
with that , the debate wraps up and moves on to the adjournment debate , tabled by labour 's jim fitzpatrick on the running of the island health trust .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: rural parity with urban areas needed - labourwelsh affairs debate
text: chris ruane , shadow wales office minister , says that ben lake 's earlier calls for `` rural parity '' with urban areas is something that labour agrees with .
mr ruane says there has been `` great regional inequality since 2010 , '' and calls austerity something which `` has blighted this land '' .
he adds that labour in wales has managed to shelter people from the worst affects of austerity since 2010 , `` but the dam is about to break '' .
`` talk is cheap , and action is what we want here today , '' he adds .
he says that hs2 will have huge implications for north wales , but that government statements on the rail link still remain vague .
farmers are `` only now seeing the deceit '' from the eu referendum campaign in terms of farming subsidies , he claims , which could be reduced as much as 40 % after the uk leaves the eu .
continued silence on tidal lagoons in the uk is `` stymieing '' the welsh government 's attempts to be the greenest area of the uk , he goes on to say .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: we are moving into a global trade war - plaid cymruwelsh affairs debate
text: jonathan edwards , wrapping up the debate for plaid cymru , calls for the uk to continue its membership of erasmus , noting that scotland is already researching this matter and the welsh government are `` way behind '' on if wales could continue to be a member of the education scheme .
he supports calls for st david 's day to be viewed as a public holiday for those in wales .

`` we are moving into a global trade war at the very time we are leaving the eu customs union , '' mr edwards states , adding that he is concerned about how the uk will stand up against the united states .
he calls for a `` dose of reality '' in the uk thinking and reporting on the brexit process .
he observes that not much progress has been made .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: we do n't want to second-guess the referendum result - ministereu withdrawal bill
text: brexit minister lord callanan once again rejects the proposal for another referendum .
rather than `` second-guess '' the referendum result , he says , the government 's priority `` is to make a success of it - not just for those who voted leave '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: bid to revoke article 50 in the event of 'no deal ' scenarioeu withdrawal bill
text: labour 's lord campbell-savours introduces an amendment which would provide for a referendum on whether brexit should go ahead in the event that the uk fails to reach a deal with the eu .
he says the negotiations as currently framed will `` undermine our economy and industrial base '' .
he argues the leave vote was prompted by the drive to `` give the system a good kicking '' , not by the desire to leave the single market and customs union , which for most are `` obscure terms '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: broadband does n't have to be bad in rural wales - plaid cymru mpwelsh affairs debate
text: plaid cymru mp ben lake calls for investment in broadband in rural and west wales , which he says are amongst the most deprived areas in western europe .
he says it is `` unacceptable '' that people just accept that broadband will be poor in certain parts of the country .
good broadband could help lift some people out of poverty , he adds .
child poverty in his constituency , ceredigion , is as high as 20 % once housing costs are taken away from the family , he says .
he calls for a fairer social security system with high quality housing being offered .
`` people should have a realistic hope of being able to pursue a career '' and should be able to afford to settle down in any part of wales , mr lake finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: minister promises new consultative process for councils after brexiteu withdrawal bill
text: local government minister lord bourne of aberystwyth insists ministers are consulting local government about where they stand after brexit , including through `` sounding board round tables '' facilitated by the local government association .
he does n't see the need to replicate the eu committee of the regions on a statutory basis as this would introduce `` unduly rigid bureaucracy '' .
but he tells peers the government will announce a new process to consult local authorities on matters they would have been consulted on through an eu committee of the regions .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: i sit on the snp benches , but i 'm a plaid cymru member too - gradywelsh affairs debate
text: the snp 's patrick grady says that he too is a member of plaid cymru , having joined in september 2014 , after wanting to show `` solidarity '' with all of those joining the snp too .
mr grady says that matters such as health , education and transport are now in the powers of devolved administrations such as the scottish parliament and welsh assembly .
he pays tribute to the `` strength of devolution '' in what these two devolved governments can do .
two-hundred thousand jobs are based on the single market and customs union , he adds , `` all of these are under threat from an extreme tory brexit '' .
he says that the people of wales have approved of devolution settlements twice , so the ongoing eu withdrawal bill in the lords must not be used as a `` power grab '' from the assembly .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peers seek brexit role for english regionseu withdrawal bill
text: lib dem lord shipley now introduces an amendment seeking a full consultative role for local authorities in the planning and decision-making processes involved in the uk 's withdrawal from the eu , and a formal mechanism in domestic law to replicate the advisory role conferred on local authorities via membership of the eu committee of the regions .
he argues : `` it 's not enough to have occasional informal discussions with mayors in england and dress it up as consultation '' .
he says he does n't want to see a situation in which deprived communities end up feeling `` even more left behind '' .

he 's backed by conservative lord porter of spalding , chair of the local government association , who says he wants to replicate `` not the bureaucracy but the ability for local government to have an input into national government '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: commons opens debate on welsh affairswelsh affairs debate
text: the house of commons moves to a debate on welsh affairs .
wales secretary alun cairns tells the chamber that there are `` exciting opportunities '' for expanding infrastructure and rail links to west wales .
mr cairns says that any large scale infrastructure projects in wales must provide value for money for both taxpayers and consumers .
he points to the circuit of wales as an example where the numbers `` just did n't add up '' .
shadow wales secretary christina rees says there is great `` uncertainty in our communities '' about the effects of brexit and from austerity .

she says that the government 's approach to austerity will do nothing other than to `` stagnate '' the economy and wages , causing `` longer queues at the food banks the length and breadth of wales '' .
`` wales needs investment , as the uk as a whole needs investment , '' ms rees says .
she adds that there is still no further clarification for welsh manufacturers and exporters on what will happen after brexit .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: putting the record straightmp for braintree tweets
text: today , in the chamber , i said there was s deep water port in the south of my constituency .
the people of great notley will be surprised to hear that .
what i meant to say was in the south of my county .
sorry .
as your device is set not to allow you to post anything on twitter until it contains a smear involving the words 'labour and corbyn ' it appears you 're account has been hacked jimbo ,
you must have confused it with one of the quite disgraceful number of pot holes that have made in and around braintree an embarrassment and dangerous place to drive and cycle
it 's ok your good at saying one thing but mean another !
get the bbc to photoshop it in
with a `` russian-looking '' submarine
i 'm surprised you do n't have an encyclopaedic knowledge of the county you were parachuted into .
( not surprised ) .
surprised you 've even heard of great notley - you never seem particularly concerned with your constituents .
were you in deep water ?
remember to send correction to hansard !
does n't sound too clever
reece mogg on the brexit sellout
i hope your honesty / clarification pays off , sir !
quality good simple apology deep water port , new brexit free trade hang on that might actually work where 's my constituency secretary dorothy ! ! !
tories greed knows no limits .
that would be handy james i 'm only in silverend so could walk to the ferry something for the future maybe
doh !
if it keeps snowing and raining , then riverside could temporarily become one !

documents.title: voters 'knew a range of outcomes ' could follow brexiteu withdrawal bill
text: brexit minister lord callanan has responded to the debate this afternoon on providing for a referendum on the deal reached between the eu and the uk .
he tells peers that the eu referendum was enacted by parliament and it `` attached no conditions , no caveats '' to the vote .
he argues voters understood `` a range of outcomes '' were possible as a result of voting for brexit .
conservative baroness altmann objects that the likely outcome - so-called hard brexit - is not what people voted for , but the minister rejoins : `` we all know what her agenda is . ''
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: minister : talks are progressing with orkambiorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: health and social care minister steve brine says it is remarkable to have 60 mps speak in such a debate , an indication of the interest in the matter .
mr brine says he is not only a government minister , but a constituency mp and also a father of two .
he pays tribute to the manufacturer of the drug , vertex , saying it knows the importance of the uk market as a potential customer for the drug .
he says that the conversations between the company and the government are progressing .
he can not give a specific answer on how long it will be before the negotiations are complete and how much the talks have moved on .
mr brine says that nice has `` a very very difficult job '' in assessing benefit analysis for drugs in use on the nhs .
there are other parts of the world where if your health insurer could not afford it , he adds , there would not even be a discussion .
he states that `` this is not the end of the story '' in treatments for cystic fibrosis sufferers .
he says that nhs england has agreed to further discussions with the manufacturers of the drug .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: watch : marion fellows ' grand-daughter has cystic fibrosisorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: moving speech by marion fellows , whose grand-daughter has cystic fibrosis .
'as a grandmother watching her going through physiotherapy , it 's heartbreaking .
her parents were told that they must n't comfort her as she needs to get used to it as she will need physio all of her life '
stunning speech from @ twitterid in yesterday 's # orkambinow debate .
# cysticfibrosis will be unrecognisable by the time her granddaughter is a grown woman but today we must fight to secure that future .
yesterday was such an important moment .
let 's make it count .

documents.title: thank you to everyone who signed the petition - labourorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: labour 's shadow health minister , sharon hodgson , thanks the 115,000 people who signed the petition in 11 days .
she says that at the start of the debate it was standing room only , which shows `` the strength of feeling '' from those across the house .
she says that while there are other drugs which can improve symptoms hugely , only one has a success rate of 1 in 20 patients , whereas orkambi works for 8 in 20 sufferers .
orkambi was approved for use for two and a half years , ms hodgson says , but no further progress has been made .
she asks to minister to elaborate on whether the manufacturers of the drug , vertex , have made progress in talks with the government and nhs england .
she calls on the manufacturer to try and revise the price of the drug to make it accessible to the nhs .
she also asks for a revision of how nice assesses medicines for long-term conditions such as cystic fibrosis .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: there must be no 'postcode lottery ' - snporkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: the snp 's marion fellows says that `` there is true cross-party agreement '' in westminster hall , but declares a personal interest , as her granddaughter has been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis .
ms fellows says the fact that so many mps attended a round table on the matter , arranged by labour 's ian austin , shows the depth of feeling about the issue .
she says that there should be `` no postcode lottery '' in treatment for people suffering from cystic fibrosis .
she wraps up by saying `` there is an overarching need '' for reform of how new drugs are assessed and if they should be provided on the nhs .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: orkambi offers 'hope ' for cf patientsorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: the snp 's david linden says he 's been tweeted at by a constituent during the debate .
she says she 's a student and with `` access to amazing drugs like orkambi , i 'll be able to make use of my degree when i graduate '' .
he says `` constituents are clear , we need orkambi now '' .
labour 's rachel maskell says the debate is about the `` hope '' that can be brought by a treatment that works .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: welsh debate held over due to bad weatherparliamentary reporter tweets
text: common is now on the general debate on welsh affairs
this debate had to be postponed from st david 's day because of bad weather .
it was granted by @ twitterid but has been rescheduled in government time .

documents.title: on to the next stage secure tenancies bill
text: after a short debate , the commons approve the secure tenancies ( victims of domestic violence ) bill at second reading - without a vote .
the legislation now progresses to its committee stage for detailed scrutiny .
the commons now moves on to a debate on welsh affairs .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: watch : 'i can plan for my future '
text: chantelle millward on orkambi drug for cystic fibrosis patients
pretty girl
cut the money from health tourists
please take the time to look at the nice report .
this is not an easy matter
so that is a reason not to

documents.title: cf patients 'do not have time to waste'orkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: conservative bob stewart says orkambi `` seems to make a huge difference '' for cystic fibrosis sufferers , successfully working for half of those with the condition .
he says the price of the drug , currently £ 104,000 a year , should be reduced if possible .
he says this can happen if the drug company , vertex , the nhs and the government get together .
`` we 're talking about people 's lives here , and their life expectancy it must be sorted and it can be , '' he declares .
labour 's tulip siddiq says `` cystic fibrosis patients do not have time to waste '' and it 's `` sad that money is getting in the way '' .
she asks what the government is doing to ensure `` fair and responsible pricing '' for treatments .
statistics from the cystic fibrosis trust suggest that the median lifespan for a cf sufferer is currently 47 years old .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: an issue 'of critical importance'secure tenancies bill
text: opening the debate , the housing minister heather wheeler says the government will conduct a review of women 's refuges in the summer .
she says the most recent lettings data shows that 1.52 % of all social lettings are for people who have left an abusive relationship .
while it is a small percentage , ms wheeler points out , `` that this is still 5000 lives '' .
this bill has already faced scrutiny in the lords and `` is in much better shape as a result , '' she adds .
this is a great example of cross-party work in this area , she finishes .
shadow communities and local government minister , melanie onn , pays tribute to colleagues in the lords who have worked hard on the bill .
`` this bill arises from a legislative error in the housing and planning act 2016 '' she states .
ms onn says she is happy that the bill is before the house today and has not been delayed `` as this is a matter of critical importance '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: commons debates secure tenancies for victims of domestic abusesecure tenancies bill
text: the house of commons now moves on to the secure tenancies bill for victims of domestic abuse .
the # securetenanciesbill will have its second reading today .
the bill aims to ensure that certain victims of domestic violence will retain a right to a 'lifetime ' secure tenancy .
find out more in our impartial briefing
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: tory peers reject the idea of a brexit deal referendumeu withdrawal bill
text: conservative lord garel-jones confesses he 's not a fan of referendums , but `` like it or not i have to accept it '' .
his party colleague lord forsyth of drumlean claims `` most of the people who support a second referendum are those who reject the decision to leave the eu - the intention is clear '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'a pretty huge question mark over our referendum result'urgent question : cambridge analytica
text: labour 's stephen kinnock tells mps that andy wigmore , director of communications for voteleave.eu , says that cambridge analytica was `` our most potent weapon '' in the referendum .
mr kinnock says that `` not a penny '' of `` donation in kind '' of hundreds of thousands of pounds was reported to the electoral commission .
he says an investigation has been launched and remarks that if cambridge analytica has acted in this way , it would `` place a pretty huge question mark over our referendum result '' .
mr hancock says that the department has seen no evidence that cambridge analytica has affected the outcome of an `` electoral event '' .
the uk needs `` to make sure that these investigations take their course , '' he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: new masters of the universe ? urgent question : cambridge analytica
text: labour 's clive efford says modern-day social media companies are showing the `` same sort of arrogance '' shown by the so-called `` masters of the universe '' before the financial crisis in 2008 .
the way they are using data is `` completely unregulated '' , he says .
in reply matt hancock says he `` agrees with the premise '' of the question and says the `` parallels are telling '' .
the attitude of social media giants has been that `` government should get out of the way '' - but he adds that the risks of social media are `` best addressed '' through legislation .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: has the government talked to facebook ? urgent question : cambridge analytica
text: home affairs committee chair yvette cooper says that cambridge analytica did some work for a russian company that is currently on the us sanctions list .
he asks if the government has been in touch with facebook to find out if there have been further data breaches .
mr hancock replies that the government has been in contact with facebook , and that this is part of a `` longer dialogue '' in making sure facebook deals with such concerns as a priority .
he does not want to have to keep coming to the house to discuss data breaches from companies , he adds , which is why it 's important to keep the law up to date .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: ex-civil service chief backs second referendum optioneu withdrawal bill
text: crossbencher and former cabinet secretary lord butler of brockwell backs the amendment providing for a referendum on the eventual brexit deal .
he explains he believes this bill is `` not an appropriate vehicle '' for a second referendum , but that it must be `` among the options '' in parliament 's quest for meaningful vote on brexit .
he says at this point it seems as though the vote would be on `` this agreement or no agreement '' and that would be `` entirely wrong '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: call for a referendum on brexit dealeu withdrawal bill
text: peers are now debating an amendment in the name of plaid cymru 's lord wigley , providing for a referendum on terms of the uk 's withdrawal from the eu .

he says of leave voters `` they did n't vote to quit with no arrangement '' with the eu , and he is `` convinced '' if that had been the proposition the referendum outcome `` would have been very different '' .
if a deal is reached with the eu , `` that wo n't be a wishy-washy brexit '' , he continues , and will be something more concrete which voters should get a say on .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: minister urged to 'get round the table ' with nhs and drug companyokambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: labour 's stephen hepburn says that orkambi `` works , it improves lives '' and that nice , who say the drug is too pricey to provide on the nhs , are `` wrong '' .
he asks the minister sitting in on the debate , health minister steve brine , to `` get round the table '' with the nhs , nice and the drug company , vertex .

conservative bim afolami says he wants the minister to `` take note of the strength of feeling over this issue '' , citing the high turnout and broad agreement from all sides , `` this is not ty for a westminster hall debate '' .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: orkambi 'must ' be made availableorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: labour 's ian austin says he 's `` not pleased '' that the debate is taking place .
he says there have been three debates , numerous petitions and it has been three years since orkambi was approved for use in the uk .
`` this drug must be made available '' he says , citing the case of a constituent who had to take 90 tablets a day and do two hours of physiotherapy .
he quotes her saying that joining a trial for the drug `` orkambi has changed my life , i quickly became well enough to live life again as a working mum '' .
she says that her hospital visits have been `` massively reduced '' and admissions are `` non-existent '' .
conservative julia lopez intervenes to ask what the saving from the reduced hospital admissions for those on orkambi could be .

mr austin agrees saying `` we should n't just be looking at the cost , we should be looking at the savings '' too , as well as the contribution to the economy that can be made by people whose quality of life is better and who can continue to work .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: data misuse is 'a goldmine'urgent question : cambridge analytica
text: a conservative dominic grieve says misuse of data is `` a goldmine '' for those who wish to breach the law but the sanctions are `` entirely inadequate '' .
he says the laws are not `` draconian enough '' and tougher action will be needed to stop data breaches .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: government call for cross-party work after breachurgent question : cambridge analytica
text: culture secretary matt hancock adds his praise of the guardian journalists who worked on the story .
he says he agrees with labour on many questions that have been raised and calls for cross-party work in this area .
he adds that the government will ensure the companies operate within the law , when it comes to `` fit and proper '' person tests .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: if true , an 'utter indictment ' of facebook - laboururgent question : cambridge analytica
text: shadow digital economy minister liam byrne says that these allegations , if true , will provide an `` utter indictment '' of big data companies operating in the uk .
he alleges that such breaches could have affected the outcomes of both elections and referendums .
he asks if it would be possible to bring forward class actions against data breaches , so that such legal action is accessible to most people .
he asks if the leaders of cambridge analytica are really fit and proper people to be running such a data company .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: mp questions cambridge university 'oversight ' of academicurgent question : cambridge analytica
text: damian collins asks the culture secretary whether he shares concerns about the ability of the cambridge academic to access information on the facebook profiles of people who did not sign up to use the app he created .
facebook knew of this `` data breach '' for over two years , he says , and `` did nothing to act against cambridge analytica '' .
he asks whether someone will be contacting cambridge university about the `` oversight '' it had of what a member of staff was up to .
he calls for someone in the uk to have powers to `` go behind the curtain '' to explore how big technoolgy companies are using data .
culture secretary matt hancock says all the considerations raised by mr collins are being `` looked into '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'clearly very worrying ' - culture secretaryurgent question : cambridge analytica
text: culture secretary matt hancock says that the alleged breach `` is clearly very worrying '' .
in the increasingly digital world , he says , it is important for people to believe that their personal data is handled correctly .
mr hancock says that the information commissioner is looking at how political parties and other bodies have used data on voters in the uk .
he adds that the government expects all bodies to comply and co-operate fully with requests for information from the information commissioners ' office .
canvassing someone 's voting intention is an everyday occurrence , mr hancock states , but how data is collected and shared in the online space has changed things .
the ico has requested further powers in order to deal with complex investigations , especially when parties involved are not willing to come forward with data they have , he adds .
`` data , properly used , has massive value , and social media is a good thing , '' he says but : `` we need rules to ensure transparency , clarity and fairness . ''
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: mps to debate row over facebook data
text: mps now move to an urgent question from culture committee chairman and tory mp damian collins on alleged misuse of data from facebook users in the us .
data firm cambridge analytica has been accused of conducting political profiling using information acquired from millions of facebook profiles , without users ' consent .
the firm said they got the information via an app designed by a cambridge university academic , and deleted it when they found out how it was sourced .
it has denied that the data was used in services it provided to donald trump 's successful 2016 presidential campaign .
mr collins has accused cambridge analytica of `` misleading '' his committee last month about its use of facebook data - a charge denied by the company 's chief executive .
read more .

documents.title: labour mp questions compliance of dover plan with wto rulesurgent question : customs after brexit
text: labour mp stephen timms asks whether the minister recognises that , without an eu-uk trade deal , not applying checks to eu goods when non-eu goods are being checked would breach wto rules .
treasury minister mel stride says he 's `` absolutely right '' to say that under wto rules , the uk will have to `` treat these various countries equally '' .
however the government is `` very confident '' there will be a deal with the eu , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: mps pack westminster hall orkambi debateorkambi treatment for cystic fibrosis debate
text: conservative paul scully is leading the debate in a packed committee room .
he says it 's the busiest he 's ever seen the room for a westminster hall debate .
he says that the government can play a role in `` pushing nhs england and vertex [ the company which manufacturers orkambi ] together '' to reach an agreement .
conservative alex chalk intervenes to say that `` profit is n't a dirty word but when it comes to cystic fibrosis , profiteering is '' .
paul scully says he wants to make a point in defence of vertex .
he says that because of the `` restricted amount of people suffering from this condition '' they 'll need to recoup their costs somehow .

`` they 're not developing the next ibuprofen '' he says , so the company should be able to recoup `` reasonable costs '' from developing the drug which is why `` the negotiation has to be above board '' .
currently the drug costs £ 104,000 a year , part of the reason why nice will not sanction orkambi 's use on the nhs .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: minister rules out cameras at irish borderurgent question : customs after brexit
text: labour chair of the home affairs committee yvette cooper asks if the government has discussed `` extensive cameras that could be part of his proposed technological solution '' to customs checks at dover , and whether this is under consideration for the irish border .

financial secretary to the treasury mel stride assures her they have `` clearly ruled out any infrastructure at the northern ireland border '' but all options will be considered for facilitating customs checks at dover .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: soubry : 'hard border ' between sweden and norwayurgent question : customs after brexit
text: conservative mp anna soubry says there is a `` hard border '' between eu state sweden and non-eu norway , despite both being in the single market .
she asks whether the minister will ensure the cost of the government 's proposed customs models have been `` fully costed '' .
mel stride says the `` exact arrangements '' that will emerge from negotiations are not yet known , but when they are they will be assessed `` very carefully '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: over 115,000 signatories to orkambi petitionhouse of commons tweets
text: more than 115,000 people signed a petition calling to make orkambi available on the nhs for people with cystic fibrosis .
mps are now debating this petition in # westminsterhall .
watch :
dear world , please drop your ideas here your brains can help i am a canadian immigrant , i am accused of being a terrorist by the crown for 17 months , because i discovered corruption i am innocent
how many people signed for 1st tier tribunal juges to stop corruption

documents.title: friction-free trade after brexit predictedurgent question : customs after brexit
text: conservative john redwood asks the minister to confirm that the uk can expect to have `` exactly the same friction-free trade with germany and france that america and china have '' .
mel stride confirms that that is right , and says the government wants to achieve trade relations with as little friction as possible .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: labour accuses minister of 'dodging ' questionsurgent question : customs after brexit
text: shadow chief secretary to the treasury peter dowd accuses the minister of having `` dodged every question '' asked by hilary benn about dover .
he asks how tariffs are meant to be `` applied and enforced '' without checks at the border .
this would be `` a breach '' of world trade organisation ( wto ) rules , he adds .
mel stride replies the government has set out its two models for a post-brexit customs arrangement , and will `` arrive at a solution which is as frictionless as possible '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: hilary benn attacks government 's customs positionurgent question : customs after brexit
text: labour chair of the exiting the eu committee , hilary benn , asks why the house was n't told of the `` new policy not checking goods at dover '' and how the promise of `` no checks at all '' can be delivered .

he inquires whether the uk would reach a reciprocal arrangement of no checks in calais , and suggests the best way to retain a friction-less border with northern ireland is to remain in a customs union .
treasury minister mel stride pledges that the government `` will not in any way create a hard border in dover '' .
he adds the government has been `` clear as to our position '' on northern ireland - not wanting a return to the borders of the past - and discussions aimed at reaching a `` sensible arrangement '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: minister : uk aiming for 'special ' eu partnershipurgent question : customs after brexit
text: financial secretary to the treasury mel stride tells mps the government has `` detailed '' two possible options for the uk 's customs arrangement with eu .
these include either a `` highly streamlined customs arrangement '' or a `` new customs partnership '' , he says .
the government is hoping to develop a `` deep and special partnership '' with the eu after brexit , he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: mps debate cystic fibrosis treatment access
text: from 4:30pm mps will take part in a westminster hall debate on the cystic fibrosis drug orkambi .
the treatment has been found to significantly reduce and slow down symptoms of the condition and is licensed in the uk .
but nice , the body that approves medical treatments for nhs use , says the £ 104,000 annual cost is too high for it to be provided to patients .
today 's debate was sparked by an e-petiton hosted on the parliament website .
it currently has more than 115,000 signatures .
the petition calls for the nhs , nice and orkambi 's manufacturer vertex pharmaceuticals to resolve negotiations around the drug `` as a matter of utmost urgency '' .
author: Westminster Hall

documents.title: mps debate post-brexit customs arrangements
text: next up is an urgent question from labour mp and brexit committee chairman hilary benn about customs arrangements at uk ports after brexit .
last week transport secretary chris grayling said customs checks will not be made at dover after the uk leaves the eu .
he added that lorries would not be stopped for checks at the kentish port , and trade would be managed `` electronically '' .
according to the sunday times , ministers have been briefed that the uk 's customs system will not be ready by the end of 2020 , when a proposed post-brexit transition period is due to finish .

documents.title: uk ministers 'do n't sit around deciding who to on'urgent question : money laundering
text: labour 's helen goodman asks about a specific person , the ukrainian oligarch dmitry firtash who , she says , has `` links to putin '' and faces extradition to the united states over alleged bribery .
he is also the owner of the disused brompton road tube station in knightsbridge .
she asks if , `` notwithstanding that he donated £ 200,000 to the tory party , an unexplained wealth order could be put out for him '' .
minister ben wallace says that the `` difference between us and russia is that ministers do n't sit around deciding who to on '' .
he says the authorities who deal with money laundering are `` independent of government , evidence based '' and `` follow the rule of law '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: hopes for 'comradely ' behavioururgent question : money laundering
text: thirty minutes into the urgent question , the speaker john bercow notes that it is only labour mps - a large number of them - standing up in the hope of asking a question .
he says : `` true to form i know they will want to behave in a comradely fashion towards each other , recognising that a long question by one will stop another . ''
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: two apartments in whitehall ? urgent question : money laundering
text: chair of the home affairs committee yvette cooper repeats claims that the first deputy prime minister of russia has two apartments in whitehall .
she asks what the government can do to establish whether this is the case .
mr wallace says he is not able to discuss an individual case at the dispatch box but the government will not `` hesitate '' to ask questions in cases where unexplained wealth is apparent .
it does not matter if these people are `` politically exposed , '' he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: uk has a long tradition of protecting rights , peers toldeu withdrawal bill
text: government spokesman lord keen of elie responds to opposition calls for extra safeguards on standards , rights and protections currently overseen by the eu .
he observes that the uk has `` a long-standing tradition , pre-dating 1972 , of ensuring rights and protections are respected nationally '' .
he tells those peers who asked which bodies will be responsible for maintaining standards , `` that will be parliament '' .
the eu is not the `` touchstone '' for standards , he says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: there are 'legitimate russians ' - ministerurgent question : money laundering
text: labour 's margaret hodge says that the government `` have not taken enough steps '' and raises concern about what is called the `` tier 1 investor visa '' in which people have to demonstrate they have £ 2m in assets which will be invested in the uk .
she states that russians are among the highest users of these kinds of visas .
she asks how the government can ensure where the £ 2m assets come from .
mr wallace states that the government has powers , within the current visa regime , to take action in such cases .
he adds that there are `` legitimate russians '' who use the visa as intended .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: snp calls for action on 'loopholes'urgent question : money laundering
text: the snp 's stewart hosie asks for a `` genuinely tough '' magnitsky amendment and calls for action on scottish limited partnerships , business structures which , he says , are one of the `` main routes for filtering dirty money into the uk '' .
he also says that `` loopholes '' at companies house should be closed because there 's `` absolutely no due diligence '' undetraken on newly formed companies .
minister ben wallace praises the snp saying it 's trying to `` work together with some sound suggestions '' .
he says the government is looking at scottish limited partnerships and promises that a magnitsky amendment will be tough .
`` anyone convicted of gross human rights abuses we will deal with people who have committed gross human rights abuse should find their existence incredibly hard , '' he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: minister turns on labour for 'woeful response ' to salisbury attackurgent question : money laundering
text: replying to john mcdonnell , the minister ben wallace says the government has `` done a lot of work '' on criminal finance , including committing to a public register of overseas ownership .
but his statement that a bill will be introduced this year prompts jeers from labour mps .
responding to the shouts , the minister says : `` when you 're bringing in so many steps to deal with criminal finance there are only so many months in the year . ''
his speech takes a more political turn as he calls labour 's urgent question a `` distraction '' from `` labour 's woeful response '' to the salisbury incident last week .
he continues : `` this government has been absolutely determined to deal with the threat posed by dirty money and harboured here in a number of properties . ''
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: questions for the government from john mcdonnellurgent question : money laundering
text: shadow chancellor john mcdonnell says that it is 12 months since he raised russian money being laundered through the city of london .
he states that the national crime agency believes that £ 90bn of foreign money is still being laundered through the uk .
he welcomes the government 's willingness to include what he calls labour 's amendments to the sanctions and anti-money laundering bill , currently working its way through the lords .
mr mcdonnell asks why a register of beneficial ownership will not be made law until 2021 .
he also wonders why the government has not included trusts in this register .
finally , he says that there were 634,000 sus activity reports filed to the authorities since october 2015 .
he asks if there are sufficient resources to deal with these reports .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: government pursuing 'crooks ' and their moneymoney laundering urgent question
text: treasury minister ben wallace says the government 's action on money laundering makes a `` long list '' .

the lengthy list of actions includes action to reverse the burden of proof on money laundering cases , making it easier to confiscate assets from those convicted of human rights abuses and support for a `` magnitsky amendment '' , to sanction russian officials involved in the death of lawyer sergei magnitsky .
he rattles through the list of measures so quickly the speaker intervenes to say that there 's `` no prohibition on breathing '' while answering an urgent question .
finishing up mr wallace says that `` whoever the crooks are , wherever they are from , we will pursue them and their cash '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: commons turns to money launderingurgent question : money laundering
text: education questions is over and the commons is on to the first urgent question of the day - from labour 's john mcdonnell , the shadow chancellor - about money laundering .
mr mcdonnell is calling on the chancellor to introduce an oligarch levy '' targeted at individuals who buy property in the uk via tax havens .
labour says the oligarch levy would introduce a tax on house purchases made by offshore trusts based in known tax havens .
labour says the tax could have a `` very direct impact '' on properties owned by russian oligarchs , citing estimates from `` independent experts '' that it could raise up to £ 875m a year .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: will there be a national review of sexual exploitation cases ? education questions
text: conservative lucy allan asks if there will be a national inquiry into cases of sexual exploitation in her constituency of telford .
she asks for it to be both current and historic .
mr hinds calls it `` a terrible case '' and promises to write to the chair of the national child safeguarding review panel to request a review of cases in telford , rotherham and oxfordshire .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: what is being done about racism in schools ? education questions
text: liberal democrat wera hobhouse asks what the government about safeguarding processes following the recent racist incident in her bath constituency .
she asks if the current safeguarding regime for students is adequate .
the education secretary says that racism should have no place in uk schools and he was `` truly shocked '' to read about the incident in bath .
where ofsted has serious concerns about a school , he says , they can give a short notice inspection to an education institution .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: standards could be undermined after brexit , peer warnseu withdrawal bill
text: peers begin day eight of eleven days of committee-stage debate on the eu withdrawal bill , which repeals the european communities act 1972 and writes eu law into uk law ahead of brexit .
committee stage is when peers carry out detailed line-by-line scrutiny of legislation , but amendments are not normally forced to a vote - this happens at report stage .

first up for discussion is an amendment from labour 's lord haskel which would require that all retained eu law relating to rights or protections will continue to be carried out by an eu entity or by an appropriate existing or newly established uk entity .
this will ensure `` standards can be enforced with clear avenues for redress '' , he argues .
without it `` standards can be undermined with no accountability '' , he warns .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: foreign office is 'diminished ' - peeroral questions
text: crossbencher viscount waverley asks the government about offering parliament more meaningful participation in foreign policy .
he suggests committees could take a more central role in `` revamping foreign policy '' in view of there being a `` diminished foreign office '' .

foreign office minister lord ahmad responds that `` far from being diminished '' his department has `` broad responsibilities '' and the government `` works constructively with all parliamentarians '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: government questioned on knife-carrying in schoolseducation questions
text: labour 's sarah jones asks what is being done to reduce the number of students carrying knives at school .
minister nadhim zahawi says the department for education continues to work with the home office on telling students that it is unacceptable to bring knives into schools .
but sarah jones says knife-carrying across schools in the uk is up by 42 % .
in her constituency of croydon central , she says , headteachers have had to cut staff in support roles .
she asks if school cuts are threatening student safety .
the minister says mps have already heard about school finances from the education secretary .
he adds that his department is working with various organisations , including the home office and ofsted , on updating guidance on school security .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: health minister : prescription drug dependence is getting worseoral questions
text: labour 's lord hunt of kings heath is asking the government to provide a network of support , nationally and locally , for people affected by dependence on prescribed drugs .
he say there 's `` woeful ignorance '' of dependence on prescribed drugs in many parts of the nhs and calls for a national action plan to address it .
he tells peers this is a `` real problem '' and `` many patients are suffering huge damage '' .
health minister lord o'shaughnessy acknowledges dependence on prescribed drugs `` is getting worse '' and says public health england has been asked to review it .
he cautions that it would `` premature '' at this stage to say what action should be taken .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: education secretary and labour shadow clash across the aisleeducation questions
text: shadow education secretary angela rayner starts her questions by congratulating andria zafirakou for winning the global best teacher prize at the weekend .

ms rayner goes on to say that the chancellor philip hammond has stated that per pupil spending is increasing in schools - and she asks if the education secretary damian hinds agrees with the chancellor .
after joining the congratulations for ms zafirakou , mr hinds states that per pupil spending is being maintained .
but ms rayner replies that the uk statistics authority has refuted the claims .
she asks if mr hinds will admit that spending per pupil will not increase and that schools will face further cuts .
mr hinds says that cash funding per pupil is increasing while `` real terms '' per pupil funding is being maintained .
he says the core schools budget will rise from around £ 41bn to £ 43.5bn .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: education questions kicks offeducation questions
text: the first question today comes from conservative alex burghart , who wants to know what is being done to help children in need .
education minister nadhim zahawi says the government is committed to helping children in need , pointing to the government review launched last friday .
mr burghart says he is fully supportive of the review and asks if data held by the department could be used to help children where necessary .
mr zahawi says the review is intended to establish best practice with partner organisations and local authorities .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: today in the house of lords
text: peers begin work at 2.30pm with questions .
they 'll be asking ministers about trafficked children , prescription drug dependency , broadband and parliamentary participation in foreign policy .
today is also the eighth day of consideration of the european union withdrawal bill at committee stage .
amendments likely to be debated today cover the irish border , the good friday agreement and parliamentary approval for the uk 's exit deal .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: today in the house of commons
text: mps start their week at 2:30pm with questions to the education secretary damian hinds and his ministers .
that 's followed by three urgent questions from 3:30pm .

shadow chancellor john mcdonnell will ask about money laundering , brexit committee chair hilary benn will ask about customs arrangements after the uk leaves the eu and the culture committee chair damian collins will ask about an alleged breach of data privacy by data analysis firm cambridge analytica .

the main business of the day is the secure tenancies ( victims of domestic abuse ) bill , which aims to give social housing tenants who have been victims of domestic violence an old-style secure tenancy .
mps will then take part in a general debate on welsh affairs .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: good afternoon
text: welcome to our live coverage of monday in parliament .
parliament gets down to work at 2.30pm with question-time in the commons and the lords .

there 's a flurry of activity in the commons this afternoon with three urgent questions : on money laundering ; customs arrangements after brexit ; and the activities of cambridge analytica , the data analysis firm .
there 's important business in westminster hall too when , at 4.30pm , mps debate a petition calling for nhs england to fund orkambi , a treatment for people with cystic fibrosis .
the lords continue to plough on with their detailed scrutiny of the eu withdrawal bill .
peers are now on to their eighth day of committee-stage debate ; three more days to go after that .
